[[File:Invisible.dialogues.night.jpg|thumb|right|
(In)visible Dialoguges, 2011, phosphorescent copies of J. Bolin's Chairs with catalogue, created by Abake (night)]] [[File:Invisible.dialogues.day.jpg|thumb|right|
(In)visible Dialoguges, phosphorescent copies of J. Bolin's Chairs with catalogue, created by Abake 2011 (day)]] '''(In)visible Dialogues''' was an art project realized at the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Arts|Royal Academy of Fine Arts]] in [[Stockholm]] in 2011. It was initiated by artist [[Per Huttner]] and biochemist [[Elias Arnér]]. The project was transgressing the boundaries of [[exhibition]], [[publication]] and [[lecture]]s in order to stimulate dialogues between art and science. The project was a sequel to the project [[Begrepp – En samling]] from 1992''(In)visible Dialogues'', Ed. E. Arnér and P. Huttner, Published by Dent-de-Leone. {{ISBN|978-91-978934-3-5}} and drew on Hüttner's experiences from projects like [[I am a Curator]]{{cite book |last = Hüttner |first = Per |authorlink = Per Hüttner |chapter=Introdictionary |title = [[I am a Curator]] |publisher = Föreningen Curatorial Mutiny |chapter-url=http://www.perhuttner.com/text/by/IAAC.book.intro.doc |chapter-format=[[DOC (computing)|DOC]] |year = 2005 |location=Stockholm |isbn = 91-631-5132-4 }} and [[Democracy and Desire]].Per Hüttner: ''[[Democracy and Desire]]'', 2007, 158 pages (A3) including 10 colour fold out pages. Languages: English, Swedish, Spanish and Rumanian. Design by Åbäke. Published by Vacio 9 and The Rumanian Cultural Institute. {{ISBN|978-91-633-0548-1}}. (In)Visible Dialogues was installed in three interconnected rooms. In the first, you saw 120 fluorescent chairs facing a blank wall. On the back of each chair a copy of the project's catalogue had been nailed and officially signed by a Professor from [[Karolinska Institutet]] and approved for publication, following local academic protocol. Each chair was an authorized copy of [[Jonas Bohlin]]'s Concrete from 1980 that had been customized by the design group Åbäke. The two flanking side rooms remained empty apart from a solitary lectern painted in the same color as the chairs and which was connected to speakers that emitted music and sounds composed for the occasion by participating sound artists [[Andy Cox]] and Richard Allalouf, Natalia Kamia, Samon Takahashi, [[Ebbot Lundberg]] and Yan Jun who interpreted a text written by Hüttner and Arnér on the importance and difficulty of dialogues between art and science. A new sound piece was played back each week.{{Cite web |url=http://www.invisibledialogues.org/sounds.php |title=The sound pieces can be heard to on this website |access-date=2012-01-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726185523/http://www.invisibledialogues.org/sounds.php |archive-date=2011-07-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Lundberg's contribution, ''There's Only One of Us Here'' was released in 2012 – his first solo album in a 25-year career. At 2pm, every Sunday in March 2011, a dialogue took place. The dialogues were devised so that a member of the scientific community dialogued with a member of the world of visual art. The audience could not see the two dialoguing people, who could not see each other either. ==Dialogue schedule== 6 March 2011 – '''Probing the Boundaries of Performance''' [[Predrag Petrovic]], M.D. Ph.D., Department of Clinical Neuroscience, Karolinska Institutet, Stockholm and [[A Constructed World]], Artists, Jacqueline Riva MFA and Geoff Lowe Ph.D., Ecole Supérieure des Beaux-Arts d'Angers, [[Angers]] 13 March 2011 – '''Probing the Boundaries of Insight''' [[Konrad Kaufmann]], Ph.D., Max-Planck-Institut für biophysikalische Chemie, [[Göttingen]] and [[Arijana Kajfes]], Artist, Stockholm, Sweden 20 March 2011 – '''Probing the Boundaries of Talent''' [[Sandra Masur]], Ph.D, Professor, [[Mount Sinai School of Medicine]], Department of [[Ophthalmology]], [[New York City]] and [[Laurent Devèze]], [[Philosopher]], [[Art Critic]] and Director of École Régional de Beaux Arts, [[Besançon]] 27 March 2011 – '''Probing the Boundaries of the Mind''' [[Veronique Wiesinger]], [[Curator]] and director for [[Alberto and Annette Giacometti Foundation]], [[Paris]] and [[Hugo Lagercrantz]], MD PhD, Professor, Karolinska Institutet, [[Astrid Lindgren Children's Hospital]], Stockholm ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.perhuttner.com/invisible.dialogues/ Official website for the project] * [http://www.konstakademien.se/ Royal Academy of Fine Arts web site (In Swedish only)] * [http://ki.se/ki/jsp/polopoly.jsp?l=en&d=130 Karolinska Institutet web site] * [http://www.perhuttner.com/ Per Huttner web site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120319005017/http://ki.se/ki/jsp/polopoly.jsp?l=en&d=30753 Elias Arnér profile at Karolinska Institutet.] [[Category:Installation art works]] [[Category:Conceptual art]] [[Category:Swedish art]]

[[Nikolai Smirnov (cinematographer)|Nikolai Smirnov]]
[[Eduard Tisse]] |editing = |distributor = |released = {{Film date|1935|11|6|df=y}} |runtime = 82 min. |country = Soviet Union |language = Russian |budget = }} '''''Aerograd''''' ({{lang-ru|Аэроград}}, also referred to as '''''Air City''''' or '''''Frontier''''') is a 1935 [[Cinema of the Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[adventure film]] by [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] director [[Alexander Dovzhenko]], a coproduction between [[Mosfilm]] and [[Dovzhenko Film Studios|VUFKU]]. It is an adventure story set in the Soviet Far East in the future. ==Plot== A [[Russia]]n outpost in Eastern [[Siberia]] comes under threat of attack by the [[Japan]]ese in this patriotic film from 1935. Aerograd is a new town with a strategically located airfield of vital interest to the government. Work on the new outpost is complicated when tensions develop between workers and a religious sect. The sect threatens to give their support to a band of marauding [[samurai]] warriors who battle for control of the region. Relations between the two countries are further strained in the days before [[World War II]], dating back to the [[Russo-Japanese War]] of 1905. In this feature, the Russians are victorious as airplanes throughout the country come to the aid of the beleaguered new town. Director Alexander Dovzhenko, long considered a giant in Russian classic cinema, also wrote the screenplay for this feature. == Cast == *[[Stepan Shagaida]] as Stepan Glushak *[[Sergei Stolyarov]] as Vladimir Slushak *[[Yevgeniya Melnikova]] *[[Stepan Shkurat]] as Vasili Khudiakov *[[Nikon Tabunasov]] as Young Chukcha *[[Boris Dobronravov]] as Aniky Shavanov *[[Yelena Maksimova]] as Maria Kudina *[[Vladimir Uralsky]] as Yefim Kosa, partisan * [[Ekaterina Korchagina-Aleksandrovskaya]] as old believer ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0026040}} * [[File:Logo of YouTube (2015-2017).svg|40px]] {{YouTube|_kZuE2ejBPU | title= Aerograd }} (English subtitles) * {{Internet Archive film|id=aerograd}} * {{Amg movie|159066}} * [http://www.kinopoisk.ru/level/1/film/43418/ ''Aerograd'' at Kinopoisk] {{ru icon}} {{Alexander Dovzhenko}} [[Category:1935 films]] [[Category:Aviation films]] [[Category:Films directed by Alexander Dovzhenko]] [[Category:Mosfilm films]] [[Category:Dovzhenko Film Studios films]] [[Category:1930s science fiction films]] [[Category:Russian-language films]] [[Category:Soviet films]] [[Category:Soviet-era Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Soviet science fiction films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian black-and-white films]] [[Category:Soviet black-and-white films]] [[Category:Russian Futurist film]] [[Category:Russian-language Ukrainian films]] {{USSR-film-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=May 2014}} An '''after action report''' (or '''AAR''') is any form of [[retrospective]] analysis on a given sequence of goal-oriented actions previously undertaken, generally by the author themselves.
The two principal forms of AARs are the [[literary]] AAR, intended for recreational use, and the analytical AAR, exercised as part of a process of [[performance evaluation]] and improvement. In most cases, AARs are a combination of both. Most analytical AARs are conducted over a contemporary problem or situation that has occurred in the past, is happening right now, or what could happen in the future.
== History == The first AARs were developed by [[army generals]]. One of the first and best examples of an AAR is [[Julius Caesar]]’s “[[Commentaries on the Gallic War]]”.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Maurer|first1=Rick|title=Feedback toolkit : 16 tools for better communication in the workplace|date=2011|publisher=Productivity Press|location=New York|isbn=1439840938|edition=2nd|url=https://books.google.com/?id=x_vgdUxhj5oC&lpg=PT57&dq=%22after%20action%20report%22%20%22Commentaries%20on%20the%20Gallic%20War%22&pg=PT57#v=onepage&q=%22after%20action%20report%22%20%22Commentaries%20on%20the%20Gallic%20War%22&f=false|accessdate=24 August 2015}}</ref>
Contemporary examples of AARs include project evaluations in [[business]], as well as summaries of large gaming sessions in [[videogame]] culture.
== Literary AARS == Literary AARs can be formal or informal documents that seek syntax and linguistic improvement. Many [[research papers]] published under an academic journal can be considered a literary AAR. There might not be much of a difference between literary AARs and analytical AARs in terms of research papers, but the key difference is analytical seeks to improve performance while literary seeks to improve style.
== Analytical AARs == Analytical AARs are formal [[documents]] intended to serve as aids to performance evaluation and improvement, by registering situation–response interactions, analyzing critical procedures, determining their effectiveness and efficiency, and proposing adjustments and recommendations.
=== Objectives === Analytical AARs have three central objectives:
* Identifying problematic issues and needs for improvement * Proposing measures to counteract problematic elements * Obtaining “lessons learned”
=== Structure === #Overview #Goals and objectives #Analysis of outcomes #Analysis of the performance shown on critical tasks #Summary #Recommendations
=== Examples === * The U.S. Army has adopted the After Action Review (AAR) as the primary method for delivering feedback after unit training exercises. Likewise, the U.S. Army Research Institute (ARI) has supported the development and implementation of AAR procedures for over 20 years. The After Action Review Process is critical to forming an After Action Report. Notes from the review often find themselves in the report. <ref>Morrison, J. E., & Meliza, L. L. (1999). Foundations of the after action review process, 81.</ref> * Another example of an After Action Report is the global status reported on [[road safety]]. Studies are conducted in order to determine how severe road safety concerns are in a particular area. After this, a report is created over the conditional event that is road safety, and a reflection is written with insight into how road safety can be improved.<ref>Disability, W. H. O. D. of V. and I. P. and, Prevention, W. H. O. V. and I., & Organization, W. H. (2009). Global status report on road safety: Time for action. World Health Organization, 1-227.</ref> * Exercise reports are a form of analytical AARs and could be peer-reviewed by an expert who might make suggestions to one's workout routine. Exercise reports find themselves following the same structure as a general AAR. A draft report can be written before workouts, and a follow-up report could be written afterward detailing steps the user could act upon in order to improve their work ethic. The exerciser looking at their own report would know what they need to improve upon in the future, and could practice that skill in order to perfect it.<ref>Blue, C. L. (1995). The predictive capacity of the theory of reasoned action and the theory of planned behavior in exercise research: An integrated literature review. Research in Nursing & Health, 18(2), 105–121. https://doi.org/10.1002/nur.4770180205</ref>
==See also== *[[After action review]]
== External links == *US Army [http://www.au.af.mil/au/awc/awcgate/army/tc_25-20/tc25-20.pdf A leader's guide to after action review] (TC25-20). *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090320201640/http://transit-safety.volpe.dot.gov/training/Archived/EPSSeminarReg/CD/documents/OHIO_DOT/SEMSAFTERACTION.pdf Guide for analytical AARs implementation]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox artwork | image_file =File:Approaching Thunder Storm MET DP248013.jpg | caption = | alt = | image_size = | title = Approaching Thunder Storm | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Martin Johnson Heade]] | subject = | year = 1859 | material = Oil on canvas | height_metric =71.1 | width_metric = 111.8 | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | city = [[New York City]] | museum = [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] }} '''''Approaching Thunder Storm''''' is an 1859 painting by American painter [[Martin Johnson Heade]]. Done in oil on canvas, the work depicts an approaching thunderstorm. It was his largest painting to date.<ref>Strazdes, 164</ref> The painting is in the collection of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/11050|title=metmuseum.org|website=www.metmuseum.org|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref> It is praised for its dramatic depiction of the threatening mood of blackening skies and eerily illuminated terrain prior to the storm itself.<ref name=":0" />
One of a series of paintings by Heade of coastal landscapes, this work was based on a sketch that Heade made of an approaching storm on [[Narragansett Bay]], Rhode Island. Here, a fisherman sits by the shore watching the storm approach; there is a faint red bolt of lightning in the left part of the sky. To his left are a dog, an iron kettle, and a spread-out boat sail. Another fisherman is rowing toward the shore, having left his sailboat out on the bay. His placement in the composition helps provide a sense of distance and a narrative for the scene.
The painting is fairly conventional for its time, but the scene is hardly [[picturesque]]. Strazdes suggests that "Heade, by refusing to prettify his scenery by association, was attempting to inject into his artistic vision a serious, monumental simplicity it had not previously possessed."<ref name="s165">Strazdes, 165</ref> The composition is very open, as if seen through a wide-angle lens, and relatively empty. The swathes of dark color are novel for a landscape work. The long horizon is an influence from Heade's contemporary, [[Frederic Edwin Church]], as in paintings such as ''[[Niagara (Frederic Edwin Church)|Niagara]]''.<ref name="s165"/>
[[File:Martin Johnson Heade -Thunder Storm on Narragansett Bay ATC.jpg|thumb|Heade, ''Thunder Storm on Narragansett Bay'' (1868)]]
Numerous [[pentimenti]] suggest that Heade altered the composition over time; for example, the hills on the horizon were originally larger and more jagged. Records suggest that ''Approaching Thunder Storm'' was exhibited at the [[National Academy of Design]] in 1860.<ref name="s165"/> In 1868, Heade painted ''Thunder Storm on Narragansett Bay'', a similar composition.
== References == {{Reflist}}
* {{Cite book |chapter=The Coming Storm |last1=Strazdes |first1=Diana J. |editor=Metropolitan Museum of Art |url=https://www.metmuseum.org/art/metpublications/American_Paradise_The_World_of_the_Hudson_River_School |title=American Paradise: The World of the Hudson River School |date=1987 |publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art |isbn=9780870994975 |pages=164-165}}
[[Category:1859 paintings]] [[Category:Paintings of the Metropolitan Museum of Art]] [[Category:Marine art]] [[Category:Luminism (American art style)]] [[Category:American paintings]]

'''Asia Cosmopolitan Awards''' is an international award established by [[Economic Research Institute for ASEAN and East Asia]] (ERIA) in the context of [[wikt:commemoration|commemoration]] of the 1300-year anniversary in 2010 of [[Heijo-kyo]] (ancient capital of [[Japan]] located in present-day [[Nara Prefecture|Nara]]) as the last destination of the ancient [[Silk Road]] and one of the first [[wikt:cosmopolitan|cosmopolitan]] cities in [[East Asia]]. It will be awarded to individuals or organizations who have made substantial and significant contributions to the development and enrichment of East Asian Community in the field of cultural and economic integration, narrowing the developmental gaps, and establishing sustainably growing society in the region.
== Outline and categories == The Asia Cosmopolitan Awards consists of three prizes: the Grand Prize, the Economic and Social Science Prize, and the Cultural Prize. Other prizes may be added as necessary. Main criteria for selection are as follows. * Grand Prize: Awarded to an individual and/or organization making the most distinguished achievements in economic, social science, or cultural fields. * Economic and Social Science Prize: Awarded to an individual and/or organization contributing to the betterment of Asia in the economic or social science fields through eminent achievements in scholarly research, business innovation, industrial technology, smart consumption activities, security/safety, social security, politics, philosophy, or other general social sciences * Cultural Prize: Awarded to an individual and/or organization contributing to the betterment of Asia in the cultural fields through eminent achievements in the arts, literature, content, cultural academic research or other cultural fields.
== The 1st Asia Cosmopolitan Awards Awardees<ref>[http://www.eria.org/press_releases/FY2012/12/asia-cosmopolitan-awards.html The 1st Asia Cosmopolitan Awards Awarding Ceremony held at NARA FORUM 2012 in Japan]</ref> <ref>[http://www.eria.org/press_releases/FY2012/11/announcement-of-the-winners-of-the-1st-asia-cosmopolitan-awards.html Announcement of the Winners of the 1st ASIA COSMOPOLITAN AWARDS]</ref>== * Grand Prize: [[Supachai Panitchpakdi]], Secretary General of the [[UN Conference on Trade and Development]] (UNCTAD) * Economic and Social Science Prize: [[Benedict Anderson]], Professor Emeritus at [[Cornell University]] * Cultural Prize: [[Takehiko Inoue]], Japanese [[Manga]] Artist * Memorable Prize: The late Hadi Soesastro, Founder of the [[Centre for Strategic and International Studies]] (CSIS)
== The 2nd Asia Cosmopolitan Awards Awardees<ref>[http://www.eria.org/2nd%20Asia%20Cosmopolitan%20Awards%20Press_Release%20of%20Laureates.pdf Announcement of the Winners of the 2nd ASIA COSMOPOLITAN AWARDS]</ref>== * Grand Prize: [[Manmohan Singh]], former Prime Minister of the Republic of India * Economic and Social Science: [[Peter Drysdale]], Emeritus Professor of Economics and Visiting Fellow, Crawford School of Economics and Government, the Australian National University ; [[Wang Gungwu]], University Professor, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, National University of [[Singapore]] and Emeritus Professor of [[Australian National University]] * Cultural Prize: [[Rithy Panh]], Cambodian Filmmaker ; [[Takarazuka Revue]] Company, Japanese theatrical music company
== The 3rd Asia Cosmopolitan Awards Awardees<ref>[http://www.eria.org/news-and-views/announcement-of-the-winners-of-the-3rd-asia-cosmopolitan-awards/ Announcement of the Winners of the 3rd ASIA COSMOPOLITAN AWARDS]</ref>== * Grand Prize: H.E. U [[Thein Sein]], Former President of the [[Republic of the Union of Myanmar]] * Economic and Social Science: Professor [[Masahisa Fujita]], Professor, Konan University, Project Professor, Institute of Economic Research, [[Kyoto University]] * Cultural Prize: H.E. Prof [[Herman Van Rompuy]], [[Haiku]] Ambassador for Japan-[[EU]] Friendship, President Emeritus of the [[European Council]]
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Refimprove|date=June 2015}} {{use British English|date=December 2017}} An '''auxochrome''' (from [[Ancient Greek language|Ancient Greek]] {{wikt-lang|grc|αὐξάνω}} ''auxanō'' "increase" and {{wikt-lang|grc|χρῶμα}} ''chrōma'' "colour") is a group of atoms attached to a [[chromophore]] which modifies the ability of that chromophore to [[Absorption (light)|absorb light]]. They themselves fail to produce the colour; but when present along with the chromophores in an organic compound intensifies the colour of the [[chromogen]].<ref name="Prince">{{cite book | title=Principles of Organic Chemistry | publisher=Jai Sai Publications | first=M. | last=Vishwanathan | location=Kollam, Kerala | page=2/30}}{{ISBN missing}}</ref> Examples include the [[hydroxyl group]] (−OH), the [[amino group]] (−NH<sub>2</sub>), the [[aldehyde]] group (−CHO), and the [[methyl mercaptan]] group (−SCH<sub>3</sub>).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gronowitz|first=Salo J. O.|journal=Arkiv för Kemi|volume=27|page=239|date=1958}}</ref>
An auxochrome is a [[functional group]] of atoms with one or more [[lone pair]]s of electrons when attached to a chromophore, alters both the [[wavelength]] and intensity of [[Absorption (light)|absorption]]. If these groups are in direct [[Conjugation (organic chemistry)|conjugation]] with the [[Pi-bond|pi]]-system of the chromophore, they may increase the wavelength at which the light is absorbed and as a result intensify the absorption. A feature of these auxochromes is the presence of at least one [[lone pair]] of electrons which can be viewed as extending the conjugated system by [[Resonance (chemistry)|resonance]].
==Effects on chromophore==
It increases the color of any [[organic compound]]. For example, [[benzene]] does not display color as it does not have a chromophore; but [[nitrobenzene]] is pale yellow color because of the presence of a [[nitro group]] (−NO<sub>2</sub>) which acts as a chromophore. But [[p-Nitrophenol|''p''-hydroxynitrobenzene]] exhibits a deep yellow color, in which the [[hydroxyl|−OH]] group acts as an auxochrome. Here the auxochrome (−OH) is conjugated with the chromophore −NO<sub>2</sub>. Similar behavior is seen in [[azobenzene]] which has a red color, but [[p-Hydroxyazobenzene|''p''-hydroxyazobenzene]] is dark red in color.
The presence of an auxochrome in the [[chromogen]] molecule is essential to make a [[dye]]. However, if an auxochrome is present in the meta position to the chromophore, it does not affect the color.
An auxochrome is known as a compound that produces a [[bathochromic shift]], also known as red shift because it increases the wavelength of absorption, therefore moving closer to [[infrared light]]. [[Woodward's rules|Woodward−Fieser rules]] estimate the shift in wavelength of maximum absorption for several auxochromes attached to a [[conjugated system]] in an organic molecule.
An auxochrome helps a dye to bind to the object that is to be colored. [[Electrolytic dissociation]] of the auxochrome group helps in binding and it is due to this reason a [[base (chemistry)|basic]] substance takes an [[acid]]ic dye.
==Explanation for the colour modification== A molecule exhibits colour because it absorbs colours only of certain frequencies and reflects or transmits others. They are capable of absorbing and emitting light of various frequencies. Light waves with frequency very close to their [[natural frequency]] are absorbed readily. This phenomenon, known as [[resonance]], means that the molecule can absorb radiation of a particular frequency which is same as the frequency of electron movement within the molecule. The chromophore is the part of the molecule where the energy difference between two different [[molecular orbitals]] falls within the range of the [[visible spectrum]] and hence absorbs some particular colours from visible light. Hence the molecule appears coloured. When auxochromes are attached to the molecule, the natural frequency of the chromophore gets changed and thus the colour gets modified. Different auxochromes produce different effects in the chromophore which in turn causes absorption of light from other parts of the spectrum. Normally, auxochromes which intensify the colour are chosen.<ref>{{cite journal | title=The Dye Spectrum | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TaGZ6a_ZXEcC&pg=PA52-IA2&dq=Chromophore+intitle:New+intitle:Scientist&hl=ml#v=onepage&q=Chromophore&intitle%3ANew&intitle%3AScientist&f=false | journal=New Scientist |date=May 1989 | volume=122 | issue=1665 | pages=52 | ISSN=0262-4079 | publisher=Reed Business Information}}</ref>
==Classification==
There are mainly two types of auxochromes:
* [[Acid]]ic: [[Carboxyl|−COOH]], [[Hydroxyl|−OH]], [[Sulfonate|−SO<sub>3</sub>H]] * [[Base (chemistry)|Basic]]: [[Amino group|−NH<sub>2</sub>]], [[Secondary amine|−NHR]], [[Tertiary amine|−NR<sub>2</sub>]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Chemical compounds]] [[Category:Color]] [[Category:Chemical reactions]]

{{advert|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Belgrade Design Week | logo = | image = | imagesize = 300px | caption = | genre = Lectures, Design labs, Competitions | date = | frequency = Annually | location = [[Belgrade]], Serbia | first = | founder_name = [[Jovan Jelovac]] | prev = <!-- [[previous event]] --> | next = <!-- [[next event]] --> | participants = International artists, designers, and entrepreneurs | attendance = | area = | budget = | patron = | organised = | people = | member = | website = http://www.belgradedesignweek.com | footnotes = }} '''Belgrade Design Week''' is an international festival established in 2005, and held once a year in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]]. The week-long conference is organized every spring and is the largest design initiative in South Eastern Europe. It covers architecture, design, fashion, publishing, and new media, as well as related fields like communications, marketing, advertising, and arts management. The event includes design labs, competitions, and presentations from international speakers like [[Karim Rashid]] and [[Daniel Libeskind]].
During the rest of the year, there are related projects such as promoting local designers, holding a branding competition for the Serbian Center for the Promotion of Science, and participating in the Partners of the Human Cities/ Project.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belgradedesignweek.com/projects/|title=Projects|date=14 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://humancities.eu/story/belgrade-design-week-welcomes-the-city-of-kragujevac-to-the-human-cities-family/|title=Belgrade Design Week welcomes the City of Kragujevac to the Human Cities/ family!|website=humancities.eu}}</ref><ref name="belgradedesignweek.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.belgradedesignweek.com/interview-with-jovan-jelovac-narativ/|title=INTERVIEW WITH JOVAN JELOVAC – NARATIV|date=1 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref> The organization also spearheaded the Belgrade 2020 project, promoting the city as a candidate for the [[European Capital of Culture]].<ref name="belgradedesignweek.com"/>
== History == First held in 2005, Belgrade Design Week festival was founded by brand consultant [[Jovan Jelovac]], a formally trained architect.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=https://www.disegnodaily.com/article/belgrade-design-week|title=Belgrade Design Week|website=DisegnoDaily}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> The conference costs about half a million euros to produce and is supported mostly through commercial and media sponsorships.<ref name=":0" /> For Jelovac, education was the primary reason for launching the summit, as well as inspiring the country's citizens through design. In 2014, the president of Serbia, [[Tomislav Nikolić]], presided over the event, mentioning how design can contribute to the country's economy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belgradedesignweek.com/the-ninth-belgrade-design-week-launched/|title=THE NINTH BELGRADE DESIGN WEEK LAUNCHED-DIZAJN PARK MAGAZINE|date=29 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref>
In 2006, designer [[Karim Rashid]] was the ambassador for the second Belgrade Design Week and spoke at the conference.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/the-king-of-kool-is-so-over-new-york/article667234/|title=The King of Kool is so over New York|last=|first=|date=2008-02-02|work=The Globe and Mail|access-date=2018-04-06|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> As a result, he later headed several design projects in Serbia's capital city.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/11/on-the-verge-belgrade-europes-latest-urban-success-story/|title=On the Verge {{!}} Belgrade, Europe's Latest Urban Success Story|last=Beaumanis|first=Viia|date=2013-10-11|website=T Magazine|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-06}}</ref> Rashid stated that he is fascinated by Belgrade and Eastern Europe in general, seeing it "as the next upcoming place - everyone is psyched and enthusiastic about the rebuilding of these poetic, romantic, artistic and very intellectual places."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sajkaca.blogspot.ca/2008/05/karim-rashid-goes-belgrade_18.html|title=Karim Rashid goes Belgrade|website=sajkaca.blogspot.ca}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2017/05/five-emerging-fashion-capitals-worth-knowing.html|title=Five Emerging Fashion Capitals Worth Knowing|work=pastemagazine.com|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/design/moma-yugoslavia-new-exhibition-architecture-concrete-brutalism-celebrate-new-york-photography-a8178471.html|title=New MoMA exhibition celebrates the concrete world of Yugoslavia|date=2018-01-25|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-GB}}</ref>
After attending the design festival in 2008, architect [[Daniel Libeskind]] left with a billion dollar, albeit controversial, commission to redevelop the Belgrade waterfront.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2015/dec/10/belgrade-waterfront-gulf-petrodollars-exclusive-waterside-development|title=Belgrade Waterfront: an unlikely place for Gulf petrodollars to settle|first=Herbert|last=Wright|date=10 December 2015|website=the Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lukabeograd.com/en/city-on-wather/master-plan/strategy.html|title=Luka Beograd :: Strategy|website=www.lukabeograd.com}}</ref> Major projects like this one are contributing to the renewal of the city.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://viaggi.corriere.it/viaggi/weekend/belgrado-hotel-ristoranti/?refresh_ce-cp|title=La nuova Belgrado: cosa vedere, gli hotel e i ristoranti|date=14 July 2016|publisher=}}</ref> Other skyscrapers and shopping malls are in the planning stages, and architectural masterpieces, like the Art Nouveau "Geozavod" building, are being restored.<ref name="auto"/> Belgrade is being compared to 1990's Berlin, seen as a decaying but alive metropolis: "Recently, the gritty city has emerged as an outpost of creative activity and urban cool on the cheap, against the lingering backdrop of socialism."
== About == The principal site of the festival changes annually with various run-down or abandoned buildings being renovated for the event. Past locations have included a palace, the bombed out hotel Jugoslavija, an abandoned department store,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.designboom.com/design/belgrade-design-week-09-the-location/|title=belgrade design week 09 the location|date=31 May 2009|publisher=}}</ref> the closed contemporary art museum, and an old factory.<ref name="designboom.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.designboom.com/design/belgrade-design-week-2014-conferences-brand-new-world-10-05-2014/|title=belgrade design week 2014 conferences open up a brand new world|date=5 October 2014|publisher=}}</ref> Every year, the conference also focuses on a common thread, for example, in 2013 the unifying theme was the square shape.<ref name="glassrpske">{{cite web|url=https://www.glassrpske.com/plus/intervju/Jovan-Jelovac-Dizajn-nije-umetnost-nego-biznis/lat/110507.html|website=glassrpske.com|title=Jovan Jelovac: Dizajn nije umetnost nego biznis|accessdate=2018-04-07}}</ref>
Approximately thirty international speakers present each year and cover a wide range of subjects, helping to promote cultural exchanges between Serbia and the rest of the world. Notable designers and artists who have spoken at the event include [[Konstantin Grcic]], [[Aylin Langreuter]], [[Christophe de la Fontaine]], [[Hella Jongerius]], [[Daan Roosegaarde]], [[Ross Lovegrove]]. [[Christophe Pillet]], [[Sacha Lakic]] and [[Patricia Urquiola]].<ref name=":0" />
In addition to the presentations, there are numerous workshops and design competitions, as well as exhibits from designers such as Israeli Eilon Armon and Swiss architect duo Lang/Baumann.<ref name="designboom.com"/>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Blackwell UK | logo = [[File:Blackwell's_logo.jpg|220px|Blackwell's]] | type = Privately held company | founder = [[Benjamin Henry Blackwell]] | area_served = UK | key_people = Toby Blackwell (Owner)
Trevor Goul-Wheeker (chairman) | industry = Retail
[[Bookselling]]
Wholesale | products = Books, [[Maps]] | revenue = {{decrease}} [[Pound Sterling|£]]54.2 million (2014){{cite news|last=Shaffi|first=Sarah|title=Blackwell's returns to profit|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwells-returns-profit|accessdate=1 March 2015|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=2 October 2014}} | operating_income = {{increase}} [[Pound Sterling|£]]600,000 (2014) | net_income = | num_employees = 1,000 | homepage = [http://www.Blackwells.co.uk/ www.Blackwells.co.uk] | location_city = [[Broad Street, Oxford|Oxford]] | location_country = England, UK | locations = 45 stores (2012){{cite web|title=Our Shops|url=http://bookshop.blackwell.co.uk/jsp/editorial/shops/index.jsp?route=shops|work=Blackwells Online|accessdate=1 February 2012}} | foundation = 1879 }} '''Blackwell UK''', also known as '''Blackwell's''' and '''Blackwell Group''', is a British [[Academic publishing|academic]] [[bookselling|book]] retailer and library supply service. It was founded in 1879 by [[Benjamin Henry Blackwell]], after whom the chain is named, in [[Oxford]] on [[Broad Street, Oxford|Broad Street]]. The firm now has a chain of 45 shops, and an accounts and library supply service. It employs around 1000 staff in its divisions.{{cite news|last=Finch|first=Julia|title=Blackwell book chain owner plans to hand firm over to staff|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/sep/08/blackwells-bookstores-staff-ownership-switch|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=8 September 2010}}{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Lisa|title=Blackwell cuts 19 from library supply business|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwell-cuts-19-library-supply-business.html|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=10 May 2011}} The Broad Street branches, which include speciality music and [[art book|art/poster]] shops, remained the only ones until expansion in the early 1990s, when at peak after taking over '''Heffers''' in [[Cambridge]] in 1999{{cite news|title=Blackwell's rationalises Heffers Branches|url=http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-miscellaneous/4668559-1.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|year=1999|agency=AllBusiness}} and [[James Thin]] in Scotland in 2002,{{cite news|last=Cave|first=Andrew|title=Blackwell wins Thin in family feud lull|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2760473/Blackwell-wins-Thin-in-family-feud-lull.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=20 April 2002}} the company had over 70 outlets. Its library supply chain serves an international market, but parts were sold off in 2009, with the [[United States|North American]] arm of '''Blackwell Book Services''' and the Australian business James Bennett sold to [[Baker & Taylor]] for their academic arm YBP Library Services.{{cite news|last=Neilan|first=Catherine|title=Blackwell Sells Library supply arm|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwell-sells-us-library-supply-arm.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=8 December 2009}} The group were also publishers, under the [[Blackwell publishing]] imprint which published over 800 journals when it was sold to [[John Wiley & Sons]] in 2007 for £572 million to form [[Wiley-Blackwell]].{{cite news|last=Osborne|first=Alistair|title=Blackwell duo bury hatchet as publisher is sold to John Wiley|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2950888/Blackwell-duo-bury-hatchet-as-publisher-is-sold-to-John-Wiley.html|accessdate=1 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=18 November 2006}} The Blackwell family have run the company since its foundation, with an [[Share (finance)|ownership]] divided between voting shares owned by the family and wealth shares owned by family and others.{{cite news|last=Denny|first=Neill|title=Blackwell's to close head office, as power shifts to staff|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwells-close-head-office-power-shifts-staff.html|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=8 September 2010}} However, there was a public dispute in 2002 between Julian 'Toby' Blackwell, the current owner of the group, and Nigel Blackwell, the former chairman of the publishing arm, about the possible sale of the publishing business. This led to an offer of £300 million from [[Taylor & Francis]]{{cite news|last=Bowers|first=Simon|title=Blackwell's journal of disquiet|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2002/jan/23/books.highereducation?INTCMP=SRCH|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=23 January 2002}} and to an eventual deal with John Wiley & Son in 2006, as a result of which Nigel Blackwell and Toby's son Philip Blackwell left the business,{{cite news|last=Wallows|first=Harry|title=Blackwell's starts fresh chapter|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/2930472/Blackwells-starts-fresh-chapter.html|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=20 January 2006}} leaving Toby Blackwell the sole family member still involved in running the company. Other family voting shares are held by a [[Trust law|trust]], which Toby's shares will transfer to when he dies, eventually bringing an end to the Blackwell family involvement with the company.{{cite news|last=Denny|first=Neill|title=Last King of Blackwell's|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/profile/last-king-blackwells.html|accessdate=2 February 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=28 May 2009}} Toby Blackwell announced in 2009 that the wealth shares would be distributed between staff, transforming the company into an [[Employee Share Ownership Plan|employee-partnership]], similar to that of retailer [[John Lewis Partnership|John Lewis]], when the company returns to profitability having spent several years experiencing losses.{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Lisa|title=Blackwell Group halves losses within a year|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/blackwell-group-halves-losses-within-year.html|accessdate=27 January 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=31 March 2011}} The company reported it was expecting to return to profit in 2012. On 29 October 2012,[http://www.thebookseller.com/news/last-minute-delay-uk-nook-launch.html ''Last-minute delay to UK Nook launch'', Lisa Campbell, The Bookseller, London]. Retrieved 8 December 2012. Blackwell's was – with [[Foyles]], [[John Lewis Partnership|John Lewis department stores]], [[Waitrose]], [[Sainsbury's]] and [[Argos (retailer)|Argos]] – among the retailers to launch the [[Barnes & Noble Nook|Nook]] [[E-book reader|e-reader]] – and from, November, the [[Nook HD]] and [[Nook HD+]] tablet computers.[https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-09/26/barnes--noble-nook-launch ''Barnes & Noble's Nook HD and HD+ tablets will come to UK in November'', Ian Steadman, wired.co.uk, 26 September,2012] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121204004015/http://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-09/26/barnes--noble-nook-launch |date=4 December 2012 }}. Retrieved 8 December 2012. ==History== [[File:Blackwell's Bookshop and White Horse, Broad Street Oxford, September 1977.jpg|thumb|The main store in Oxford in 1977]] The company was founded in 1879 by [[Benjamin Henry Blackwell]], son of the first city librarian, who having finished his education at 13, was apprenticed to a local bookseller for a [[£sd|shilling]] a week. His father, Benjamin Harris Blackwell, had been heavily involved in the [[Temperance movement|Temperance Society]]. The society promoted, as well as religion, self-education and also encouraged reading. The society provided separate rooms for non-alcoholic refreshment and silent reading. A religious family, the Blackwells had also become involved with the Temperance Society due to Benjamin's father being [[teetotal]], and as a protest against the government making money from the [[excise duty]] on alcohol.{{cite web|title=48 – 51 Broad Street, Oxford|url=http://www.headington.org.uk/oxon/broad/buildings/north/48,49,50,51.htm|work=Broad Street Oxford|publisher=Headington|accessdate=27 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110702063215/http://headington.org.uk/oxon/broad/buildings/north/48%2C49%2C50%2C51.htm|archivedate=2 July 2011|df=}} The flagship shop at 48–51 [[Broad Street, Oxford]], was originally only twelve feet square but quickly grew to incorporate the upstairs, cellar and neighbouring shops. Benjamin Henry Blackwell was well respected in Oxford and was elected the first [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] councillor for Oxford North. [[Basil Blackwell]], Benjamin Henry's son, became the first Blackwell to go to university; he was awarded a scholarship at [[Oxford University]]'s [[Merton College, Oxford|Merton College]]. He was expected to join the family firm, however, which he did in 1913, after a spell as an apprentice publisher in London. He was tasked with expanding his father's publishing business. [[File:Norrington room.jpg|thumb|left|The "Norrington Room", contains more than 160,000 books on 3+ miles of shelving]] The first Blackwell publication, ''Mensæ Secundæ: verses written in [[Balliol College, Oxford|Balliol College]]'' by [[H.C. Beeching]], was printed in 1897. Blackwell's began the careers of many writers: [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s first poem, "Goblin's Feet", was published in 1915. To promote universal access to literature, Blackwell's pioneered a series of cheaper books, from a one-volume [[Shakespeare]] to "[[£sd|3-and-6]] novels". The publishing company was merged into the main company in 1921, and a scientific section was added in 1939. When Benjamin Henry died in 1924, Basil Blackwell took over from his father, and went on to head the company for over sixty years. Basil Blackwell also wanted to preserve fine printing. After rescuing the Shakespeare Head Press, he commissioned [[belles-lettres]], including well-known classics such as the [[Pilgrim's Progress]], the works of the [[Brontë]]s and a complete version of [[Geoffrey Chaucer|Chaucer]]'s [[Canterbury Tales]]. In 1966, the Norrington Room was opened, named after [[Arthur Lionel Pugh Norrington|Sir Arthur Norrington]], the President of [[Trinity College, Oxford|Trinity College]] and extending under part of Trinity College. It boasts three miles (5 km) of shelving and at {{convert|10000|sqft|m2}} merited an entry in the ''[[Guinness Book of Records]]'' as the largest single room selling books.{{cite book|title=The Guinness Book of Records|year=1967|publisher=Guinness Superlatives Limited|location=London|isbn=0-900424-00-1|page=123|edition=14th}} ===Recent history=== The company has followed a determined policy since the 1990s to spread out from its traditional Oxford base and take on a much broader UK presence. In 1995, Blackwell's became the first bookshop in the UK to allow its customers to purchase online from a catalogue of over 150,000 titles, and opened a flagship shop in London the same year, at 100 [[Charing Cross Road]], which is now one of the company's six most prominent shops. Blackwell's took over the Heffers bookshops in [[Cambridge]] in 1999, and in 2002 acquired the academic bookshops of [[James Thin]] in Scotland. Blackwell's now has over 60 retail outlets across the UK, including a number of medical and other specialist bookshops, and even a shop in [[Aberdeen]] specialising in the [[oil industry]]. Both the Oxford and London flagship shops have won Bookseller of the Year at the [[British Book Awards]]. The company is still in the hands of the Blackwell family. Support for its activities, including Blackwell's Online, is based at Beaver House in Oxford. The company was to be partially funded by Toby Blackwell Limited in 2012.{{cite news|last=Campbell|first=Lisa|title=Revenue drops but losses down at Blackwell|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/revenue-drops-losses-down-blackwell.html|accessdate=16 April 2012|newspaper=The Bookseller|date=26 March 2012}} ==Locations== Blackwell's maintains over 40 retail outlets across the UK, with flagship stores located in [[Oxford]], [[Cambridge]], [[South Bridge, Edinburgh|Edinburgh]] and [[High Holborn|London]]. Other branches are located on university campuses or are specialist branches, focusing on Music and Art. ===Gallery=== Image:Blackwell bookstore.jpg|Flagship branch, 48-51 [[Broad Street, Oxford]] File:Blackwell's. (14604009310).jpg|[[South Bridge, Edinburgh]] File:Blackwell University Bookshop, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds (4th May 2010).jpg|Woodhouse Lane, [[Leeds]] File:Blackwell's University Bookshop - geograph.org.uk - 1027633.jpg|Cambridge Road, [[University of Portsmouth]] File:Blackwell UK Reading.JPG|Whiteknights, [[University of Reading]] File:Blackwells Sheffield.jpg|Portobello Street, [[University of Sheffield]] File:Blackwells, Charing Cross Road.jpg|The former [[Charing Cross Road]] store, London File:Heffer's Bookshop - geograph.org.uk - 1335907.jpg|Heffers Sound, [[Trinity Street, Cambridge]] File:Blackwell UK Music, Broad Street, Oxford.jpg|Blackwell's Music, previously at 23-25 Broad Street, Oxford File:Art poster Blackwells Oxford.jpg|Blackwell's Art and Poster Shop, 27 Broad Street, Oxford ==See also== {{Portal|Companies|Books}} * [[Books in the United Kingdom]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Blackwell UK}} * [http://www.blackwell.co.uk/ Blackwell Online] * [https://twitter.com/blackwellbooks Blackwell Twitter] * [http://www.oxfordcityguide.com/TouristInfo/SightSeeing.html Photo and other information on OxfordCityGuide.com] {{Bookstore Chains}} [[Category:Retail companies established in 1879]] [[Category:Book publishing companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Shops in Oxford]] [[Category:Privately held companies of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Bookshops of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Book selling websites]] [[Category:Companies based in Oxford]] [[Category:British brands]] [[Category:Book distributors]]

[[File:Granit Resort NY1.jpg|thumb|The former Granit Resort/The Hudson Valley Resort & Spa in 2015]] '''Borscht Belt''', or '''Jewish Alps''', is a nickname for the (now mostly defunct) summer resorts of the [[Catskill Mountains]] in parts of [[Sullivan County, New York|Sullivan]], [[Orange County, New York|Orange]], and [[Ulster County, New York|Ulster]] counties in [[New York (state)|New York]]. [[Borscht]], a soup associated with immigrants from eastern Europe, was a colloquialism for "Jewish". These resorts were a popular vacation spot for [[New York City]] [[Jews]] between the 1920s and the 1970s.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.brown.edu/Administration/News_Bureau/1995-96/95-062i.html |title=Catskills Institute: Jewish scholars study history, cultural significance of the Borscht Belt | publisher= [[Brown University]]| location=Providence, Rhode Island| date=November 29, 1995|accessdate= August 21, 2017| archivedate= August 20, 2017| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820162242/http://www.brown.edu/Administration/News_Bureau/1995-96/95-062i.html| deadurl=no}}</ref> Most Borscht Belt resorts hosted traveling Jewish comedians and musicians, and many who later became famous began their careers there.
The tradition of Borscht Belt entertainment started in the early twentieth century with the indoor and outdoor theaters constructed on a 40-acre (16-hectare) tract in [[Hunter, New York|Hunter]], New York, by [[Yiddish theater]] star [[Boris Thomashefsky]].<ref>https://www.npr.org/2017/08/21/545027326/jerry-lewis-on-his-borscht-belt-childhood-and-the-lonely-work-of-comedy</ref>
The 1987 films ''[[Dirty Dancing]]'' and ''[[Maureen Stapleton#Filmography|Sweet Lorraine]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|title=Overnight fire destroys Heiden Hotel of 'Sweet Lorraine' fame|work=[[Times Herald-Record]]|location=Middletown, New York|publisher=Dow Jones Local Media Group, Inc.|date=May 18, 2008|accessdate=June 9, 2010|archivedate=February 1, 2013|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130201165544/http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref> reflect on the bygone era.
Beginning in the 1980s, the growth of air travel made the Catskills less attractive, so many of the resorts eventually closed, although Jewish culture has remained present. A large percentage of the region comprises summer homes and bungalow colonies (including many of the historic colonies) for [[Orthodox Jewish]] families,<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Frankfurter|first=Yitzchok|title=Ruins of the Borscht Belt|url=https://issuu.com/amimagazine/docs/epub_ami136|magazine=[[Ami (magazine)|Ami]]|date=Sep 15, 2013|issue=136|page=172|access-date=Nov 2, 2016}}</ref> primarily from the [[New York metropolitan area]], as well as year-round dwellers.
Resorts still are operating in the region, including Villa Roma, an Italian American resort, [[Soyuzivka]] and Xenia, Ukrainian cultural resorts, and the Skazka and Hotel Pine, Russian cultural resorts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skazka.us|website=Skazka.us|title=Skazka Resort|date=|accessdate=2011-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://xeniaresort.net|title=Xenia Resort|website= XeniaResort.net|date=|accessdate=2011-08-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianresort.net|title=Hotel Pine|website=RussianResort.net|date=|accessdate=2011-08-25}}</ref> Additionally, motorsports enthusiasts are drawn to the area visiting the [[Monticello Motor Club]].
==History== Borscht Belt hotels, bungalow colonies, [[summer camp]]s, and קאָך-אַליינס ''kokh-aleyns'' (a [[Yiddish language|Yiddish]] name for self-catered [[boarding house]]s, literally, "cook-alones") were frequented by families of middle and working class Jewish New Yorkers, mostly [[Ashkenazi]] Jewish immigrants. [[Antisemitism]], particularly in the 1940s, '50s, and '60s, meant that they were often denied accommodation elsewhere.<ref>E. Raab and G.J. Selznick: Major Social Problems. Joanna Cotler Books, 1974 (3rd edition). {{ISBN|0060452994}}.</ref>
Some of the Catskill hotels were converted from farms that immigrant Jews had started in the early 1900s. As the area grew, it began to cater specifically to Jews, providing kosher food, synagogues, and other features of Jewish communities, including entertainment. The area became known as "The Jewish Alps", and the [[Sullivan County, New York|Sullivan County]] portion as "Solomon County".<ref name="hvmag">{{cite web | last=Levine | first=David | date=August 8, 2014 | title=History of Borscht Belt Hotels and Bungalow Colonies in the Catskills | url=http://www.hvmag.com/Hudson-Valley-Magazine/August-2014/History-of-Borscht-Belt-Hotels-and-Bungalow-Colonies-in-the-Catskills/ | work=[[Hudson Valley (magazine)|Hudson Valley]] | publisher=Today Media | accessdate=May 26, 2017 | archivedate=2016-09-18 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160918130642/http://www.hvmag.com/Hudson-Valley-Magazine/August-2014/History-of-Borscht-Belt-Hotels-and-Bungalow-Colonies-in-the-Catskills/# | deadurl=no | df= }}</ref>
From the 1920s through the 1970s,<ref name="Tablet Mag">{{cite web | author=[[Marisa Scheinfeld]]| url= http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-arts-and-culture/102787/the-ruins-of-the-borscht-belt |title=The Ruins of the Borscht Belt|work = [[Tablet Magazine]]|date=June 15, 2012 |accessdate=March 2, 2013|archivedate= June 12, 2017| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170612092904/http://www.tabletmag.com/jewish-arts-and-culture/102787/the-ruins-of-the-borscht-belt|deadurl=no}}</ref> nearly all notable Jewish entertainers would hone their skills at resorts in the Sullivan County area. [[Fallsburg, New York|Fallsburg]] became the catalyst for American [[stand-up comedy]].<ref name="The Last Catskills Resort">{{cite web | last=Laskow |first=Caroline| last2=Rosenberg| first2=Ian | url= http://www.thirteen.org/metrofocus/2012/01/last-resort-dirty-dancing-and-the-legacy-of-the-jewish-catskills/ |title=Last Resort: ‘Dirty Dancing’ and the Catskills Legacy | publisher=MetroFocus ([[WNET]]) |location=New York City| date=January 6, 2012|accessdate=March 2, 2013|archivedate=July 6, 2017|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170706113251/http://www.thirteen.org/metrofocus/2012/01/last-resort-dirty-dancing-and-the-legacy-of-the-jewish-catskills/| deadurl=no}}</ref> Comedy legends, including [[Woody Allen]], [[Rodney Dangerfield]], [[Jerry Seinfeld]], and [[Henny Youngman]], performed there,<ref name = "hvmag" /> as did [[Sid Caesar]], [[Billy Crystal]], [[Buddy Hackett]], [[Gabe Kaplan]], [[Andy Kaufman]], and [[Joan Rivers]].<ref name="The Last Catskills Resort" /> [[Jerry Lewis]] worked as a busboy while his parents did a vaudeville act. He would entertain customers while cleaning tables, giving him a chance to hone his skills while upping his tips.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/21/545027326/jerry-lewis-on-his-borscht-belt-childhood-and-the-lonely-work-of-comedy|title=Jerry Lewis On His Borscht Belt Childhood And The Lonely Work Of Comedy}}</ref><!--[[Mel Blanc]], [[Milton Berle]], [[Jack Benny]], [[Danny Kaye]] and [[Red Buttons]] made an early living at the night clubs here, as would Hollywood stars [[Mel Brooks]], [[Don Rickles]]--> Famed [[boxing|prize fighters]] like [[Rocky Marciano]] and [[Sonny Liston]],<ref name="Baltimore Sun mistake">{{cite web| url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-07-23/news/1997204072_1_concord-catskills-fallsburg| title=Unbuckling of the Borscht Belt| last=Matthews| first=Joe| date=July 23, 1997| work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]| location=Maryland| accessdate=March 2, 2013| archivedate=January 17, 2017| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170117230942/http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-07-23/news/1997204072_1_concord-catskills-fallsburg| deadurl=no| df=}}</ref> and [[Muhammad Ali]], [[Leon Spinks]] and [[Floyd Patterson]]<ref name="Fighting for the Borscht Belt">{{cite web | last =Klein| first=Binnie |url=http://forward.com/articles/131273/fighting-for-the-borscht-belt/ |title=Fighting for the Borscht Belt|work = [[The Forward]] |publisher=The Forward Association| date=September 15, 2010 | accessdate=March 2, 2013| archivedate= December 21, 2016|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20161221195337/http://forward.com/articles/131273/fighting-for-the-borscht-belt/|deadurl=no}}</ref> trained there. Millions of tourists, especially New Yorkers, came to swim in the lakes and oversized hotel pools, to ski or ice-skate<ref name="Tablet Mag" /> or take lessons in golf, tennis, and dancing. No fewer than 538 hotels sprang up in this area of Eastern New York.<ref name="Tablet Mag"/>
Well known resorts in the area included [[Concord Resort Hotel|The Concord]], [[Grossinger's]], [[Brickman's]], [[Brown's Hotel (Catskills)|Brown's Hotel]], [[Kutsher's Hotel|Kutsher's Hotel and Country Club]], the [[Nevele Grand Hotel|Nevele]], Friar Tuck Inn, Gibber's, Gilbert's, Granit, the Woodbine Hotel, the Heiden Hotel, Irvington, Lansman's, The Laurels Hotel and Country Club, The Pines Resort, [[Raleigh Hotel (South Fallsburg, New York)|Raleigh]], Silverman's River View Hotel, Stevensville, Stiers, the Tamarack Lodge, the Olympic, and the Windsor Regency.
Two of the larger hotels in High View (north of [[Bloomingburg, New York|Bloomingburg]]) were Shawanga Lodge<ref>{{cite web | last=Dan | first = Abby |date=n.d. | title= History | url=http://shawanga.com | publisher=Shawanga.com (fan site) |accessdate= November 11, 2016| archivedate=May 21, 2017| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170521222001/http://shawanga.com/| deadurl=no}} Collection of photographs and memorabilia.</ref> and the Overlook. In 1959, the Shawanga hosted a conference that marked the beginning of serious research into lasers.<ref name='Beam'>{{cite book | last = Hecht | first = Jeff | title = Beam: the race to make the laser | publisher = Oxford University Press | year = 2005 | location = Oxford, UK | page = 101 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6jOnlRViWPoC | isbn = 978-0-19-514210-5 }}</ref> The hotel burned to the ground in 1973.<ref>{{cite book | last=Roosa | first=Monoka A. | date= 2007 | title= Mamakating | publisher = Arcadia Publishing| location= publocation | page=29}}</ref> The Overlook had entertainment and summer lodging through the late 1960s and was operated by the Schrier family. It included a main building and about 50 other bungalows, plus a five-unit cottage just across the street. It remains in a different form, no longer functioning as it was in its heyday.
The [[New York, Ontario and Western Railway|New York, Ontario & Western Railway]] carried passengers to the resorts from [[Weehawken, New Jersey]], until 1948. The railroad was abandoned in 1957. Despite the improvement of roads such as the original [[New York State Route 17]], the area is no longer a major travel destination.
The decline of the Catskills resorts was apparent as early as 1965. Entertainment in America was changing as the country ushered in the [[jet age]].<ref name="Tablet Mag" /> As ethnic barriers in the U.S. began to fall and travel to distant resorts became easier and cheaper, fewer Jewish American families in New York City went to the Catskills. By the early 1960s, between a quarter and a third of Grossinger's annual visitors were non-Jewish.<ref name=AJones>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Abigail|title=Beautiful ruins: The Catskills may be dying, but the memories live on|url=http://forward.com/articles/183901/rediscovering-beauty-amid-ruins-of-once-glorious-c/?p=all|accessdate=October 27, 2013|work=The Forward|publisher=The Forward Association| date=September 27, 2013|archivedate= March 6, 2016|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160306111031/http://forward.com/culture/183901/rediscovering-beauty-amid-ruins-of-once-glorious-c/?p=all|deadurl=no}}</ref> Even the universalization of [[air conditioning|air-conditioned]] hotels across America drew customers away from the aging resorts primarily built before this innovation became popular.<ref name="Baltimore Sun mistake" /> In the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|social and cultural upheavals of the 1960s]], traditional resort vacations lost their appeal for many younger adults.<ref name=AJones />
Smaller, more modest hotels such as Youngs Gap and the Ambassador found themselves in a niche with a vanishing clientele and closed by the end of the 1960s.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} By the mid-1990s, nearly 300 hotels and motels had gone out of business in Sullivan County.<ref name="Baltimore Sun mistake" />
The 1970s took a toll on more lavish establishments such as the Flagler and The Laurels.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5it7KmNphMo</ref> In 1986 Grossinger's closed for renovations, and the property was abandoned by new owners midway through work. Grossinger's largest historic rival (and the largest of all the Borscht Belt resorts), the Concord, benefitted only temporarily, filing for bankruptcy in 1997 and closing a year later.
In 1987, New York's mayor [[Ed Koch]] proposed buying the Gibber Hotel in Kiamesha Lake to house the homeless. The idea was opposed by local officials.<ref>{{cite news |authorlink=Joyce Purnick | first=Joyce | last=Purnick | date=April 4, 1987 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/04/nyregion/catskills-hotel-suggested-for-homeless.html | work=The New York Times | title=Catskills Hotel Suggested For Homeless | accessdate=April 26, 2010}}</ref> The hotel instead became a religious school, like many old hotels in the Catskills.<ref>[http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelframes.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228045158/http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelframes.html |date=February 28, 2009 }}</ref>
== Legacy == {{update|date=September 2017}}
Plans are now in place by those who purchased the former Borscht Belt resorts [[Concord Resort Hotel]] and [[Grossinger's]] to work with [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in an attempt to bring gambling to the region. Because the Borscht Belt's prime has long passed and many of the resorts are abandoned, developers believe this is the only way to revitalize the region to the popularity it once had by attracting guests to world-class casinos and resorts such as the ones in [[New Jersey]] and [[Connecticut]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} However, large-scale casino plans have not come to fruition, mainly because there are no [[Indian reservation]]s anywhere near the area (the [[Mohawk tribe]]'s effort to build a Catskills casino was rejected for this very reason). Instead, the state government proposed legalizing off-reservation gambling, which required a positive referendum, passed in November 2013.
The Heiden Hotel in [[South Fallsburg, New York|South Fallsburg]], which was the location of the movie ''[[Maureen Stapleton#Filmography|Sweet Lorraine]]'' starring [[Maureen Stapleton]], was destroyed by fire in May 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|title=Overnight fire destroys Heiden Hotel of 'Sweet Lorraine' fame|work=[[Times Herald-Record]]|location=Middletown, New York|publisher=Dow Jones Local Media Group, Inc.|date=May 18, 2008|accessdate=June 9, 2010|archivedate=February 1, 2013|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130201165544/http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080518/NEWS/80518002|deadurl=no|df=}}</ref>
The Stevensville Hotel in [[Liberty (town), New York|Swan Lake]], which was owned by the family of [[David G. Friehling]], who pleaded guilty as an accomplice of [[Bernard Madoff]]'s, has reopened as the Swan Lake Resort Hotel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Steve Israel|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20090322%2FNEWS%2F903220321|title=Madoff mess has local link|work=Times Herald-Record|location=Middletown, New York|publisher=GateHouse Media|date=|accessdate=June 9, 2010|archivedate=2017-08-21|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6stPIKkjU?url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20090322%2FNEWS%2F903220321#|deadurl=yes|df=}} Additional [[ WebCitation archive]] August 21, 2017.</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelnews/rebuild.html |title=Reinventing the Catskills|first=Rich|last=Newman|date=n.d.| publisher= The Catskills Institute (Brown University) |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227094255/http://catskills.brown.edu/hotelnews/rebuild.html |archivedate=February 27, 2009 }}</ref>
The former Homowack Lodge in [[Spring Glen, New York]], was converted into a summer camp for [[Hassidic]] girls. Officials of the state Department of Health ordered the property evacuated in July 2009, citing health and safety violations.<ref>{{cite news |first=Victor |last=Whitman |title=New York wants sect to leave old resort |date=July 16, 2009 |work=Times Herald-Record|location=Middletown, New York}}</ref><!--dead, non-archived; presumably still available in hard copy print newspaper-->
The Granit later began operating as the [[Hudson Valley Resort]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Hudson Valley Resort|website=HudsonValleyResort.com|url=http://www.hudsonvalleyresort.com/}}</ref>
The Tamarack Lodge caught fire in 2012, and 30 buildings were partially or completely destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hudsonvalley.ynn.com/content/top_stories/579812/massive-fire-at-tamarack-lodge-visible-for-miles |title=Massive fire at Tamarack Lodge visible for miles |website=hudsonvalley.ynn.com |date= |accessdate=2012-04-08}}</ref>

Drone Video footage of The Pines and Grossinger's. * [http://www.brown.edu/Research/Catskills_Institute/ The Catskills Institute] * {{cite book |last=Klein |first=Rich |date=November 10, 2016 |title=The Catskills of Sullivan County: A Photography Journey |location= |publisher=BookBaby |isbn=978-1483583532 |author-link= }} * {{cite book |last=Scheinfeld |first=Marisa |date=2016 |title=The Borscht Belt: revisiting the remains of America's Jewish vacationland |location=Ithaca, NY |publisher=Cornell University Press |isbn=9781501700590 |author-link= }}
