{{short description|An Anglo-Saxon sword, dating from the late 9th to early 10th centuries AD}} {{infobox artefact |name = Gilling sword |image =Gilling Sword - diagonal - YORYM 1977 51.JPG |image_caption =The Gilling sword |material = |size = |writing = |created = late 9th to early 10th Century AD |period = [[Anglo-Saxon]] |discovered_date = 1976 |discovered_place = [[Gilling West]], [[North Yorkshire]] |location = Medieval Gallery, [[Yorkshire Museum]], York |id = }} The '''Gilling sword''' is an Anglo-Saxon sword, dating from the late 9th to early 10th centuries AD, found by a schoolboy in a river in 1976 and subsequently acquired by the [[Yorkshire Museum]].
==Discovery== The sword was discovered on 9 April 1976 by nine-year old Gary Fridd on the north side of Gilling Beck, in [[Gilling West]], [[North Yorkshire]]. At the Coroner's inquisition for [[Treasure trove#England and Wales common law|treasure trove]], held in September of the same year, a police officer identified the find spot as "33 feet east of a bridge and two feet from the water's edge". He also identified that a mechanical extractor had recently been working in the area where the sword was found, offering a reason for its unusual discovery. The sword was not declared treasure and became the property of the finder.<ref name='March'>{{cite journal |url=http://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/archiveDS/archiveDownload?t=arch-769-1/dissemination/pdf/vol30/30_093_099.pdf |author1=Watkin, J. R. |date=1986 |title=A late Anglo-Saxon sword from Gilling West, N. Yorkshire |journal=Medieval Archaeology |volume=30 |page=93–99}}</ref> The finder appeared on the children's television programme ''[[Blue Peter]]'' to talk about his discovery and both he and the sword were awarded [[Blue Peter badge|''Blue Peter'' badges]].<ref>{{cite news |title=A heritage to treasure |url=https://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/features/5022865.a-heritage-to-treasure/ |accessdate=9 November 2018 |publisher=Northern Echo |date=23 February 2010}}</ref><ref name='YM'>{{cite web |url=https://www.yorkshiremuseum.org.uk/collections/collections-highlights/the-gilling-sword/ | title=Collections Highlights: The Gilling Sword |publisher=Yorkshire Museum |accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref>
The sword was purchased at auction by the Yorkshire Museum in 1977.<ref name='March' />
==Description== [[File:Gilling Sword - hilt - YORYM 1977 51.JPG|thumb|Detail of the decoration on the hilt]] The whole sword measures {{convert|838|mm}} in length, with a maximum width of {{convert|86|mm}} across the guard. The sword blade is [[:wiktionary:bifacial|bifacial]] (double edged) and the hilt is decorated in silver with a combination of geometric and [[:wiktionary:floriate|floriate]] (depicting flowers, leaves and foliage) designs.<ref name='YM' />
The blade itself measures {{convert|700|mm}} in length from the guard. It tapers gradually from the guard, where it measures {{convert|52|mm}} wide. The blade has a shallow [[Fuller (weapon)|fuller]] along its length and traces of [[pattern-welding]] are visible on its surface. The pommel is decorated with strips of silver and five matching strips are visible across the grip.<ref name='March' />
==Significance== The form and decoration of the Gilling sword places it within a group of late Anglo-Saxon swords classified as 'type L'; regarded as typical Anglo-Saxon swords of the Viking period and it has been compared to a similar example from [[Fiskerton, Lincolnshire]]. The sword may originally have derived from a grave, which had been disturbed by the mechanical excavator mentioned in the Coroner's report.<ref name='March' />
==Public display== [[File:Gilling sword (Yorkshire Museum).jpg|thumb|The Gilling sword on display in the Yorkshire Museum in 2010]] The sword is in the collection of the Yorkshire Museum. It appeared in the exhibition "The Vikings in England", which was opened by the [[Charles, Prince of Wales|Prince of Wales]] on 30 March 1982 and was seen by over 235,000 visitors before it closed in October of the same year. This exhibition was awarded the [[European Museum of the Year Award|European Museum of the Year]] Special Exhibition Award as a result of the presentation of the exhibition in the Museum and for additional educational projects organised by the curator [[Elizabeth Hartley (archaeologist)|Elizabeth Hartley]].<ref name ='Pyrah'>{{cite book|author1=Pyrah, B. J. |date=1988 |title=The history of the Yorkshire Museum and its geological collections |chapter=A Modern Museum (1970-1988) |publisher=North Yorkshire County Council |pages=134–148 |ISBN=1850720428}}</ref>
When the Museum was closed in 2010 for a major refurbishment, the Gilling sword (along with the other key objects from the Museum) were displayed at the [[British Museum]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/york/hi/people_and_places/arts_and_culture/newsid_8512000/8512052.stm |author1=Green, C. |date=12 February 2010 |title=York's medieval treasures on show at the British Museum |publisher=BBC York & North Yorkshire |accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref> It returned to the Yorkshire Museum for the new exhibition opening on 1 August 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/gallery/2010/jul/28/yorkshire-museum |title=Yorkshire Museum gets a makeover |author1=Kennedy, M. |date=30 July 2010 |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref>
In 2013 it was included in the permanent medieval exhibition "Capital of the North".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/10328057.Bigging_up_the_North/ |date=2 April 2013 |title=Bigging up the North |work=Northern Echo |accessdate=5 October 2018}}</ref>
From 2017 it formed part of a touring exhibition titled 'Viking: Rediscover the Legend' and is displayed alongside the [[Vale of York Hoard]] and the [[Cuerdale Hoard]], with the tour starting at the Yorkshire Museum and subsequently including [[Atkinson Art Gallery and Library]] in Southport, [[Norwich Castle Museum]], and the [[University of Nottingham]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.yorkpress.co.uk/news/15282835.Face_to_face_with_the_Vikings/ |author1=Lewis, S. |title=Face to face with the Vikings |date=12 May 2017 |publisher=[[York Press]] |accessdate=24 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.minsterfm.com/news/local/2291242/a-new-understanding-of-the-vikings/ |title=A new understanding of the Vikings |publisher=[[Minster FM]] News |date=18 May 2017 |accessdate= 24 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.archaeology.co.uk/articles/reviews/review-vikings-rediscover-legend.htm |title=Review – Viking: Rediscover the Legend |author1=Hilts, C. |date=30 October 2017 |publisher=Current Archaeology |accessdate= 5 October 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:1976 in England]] [[Category:Anglo-Saxon art]] [[Category:Medieval European metalwork objects]] [[Category:History of North Yorkshire]] [[Category:Collections of the York Museums Trust]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in North Yorkshire]] [[Category:1976 archaeological discoveries]] [[Category:Medieval European swords]]

revision.comment: use Wikisource for EB1911 ref., replacing archive of dead link
revision.text:
{{other uses}} [[File:Rom, Domitilla-Katakomben, Der gute Hirte.jpg|thumb|200px|The Good Shepherd, c. 300-350, at the [[Catacombs of Rome#Catacombs of Domitilla|Catacombs of Domitilla]], [[Rome]]]] The '''Good Shepherd''' ({{lang-el|ποιμήν ο καλός}}, ''poimḗn o kalós'') is an image used in the [[pericope]] of [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#10:1|John 10:1-21]], in which [[Jesus Christ]] is depicted as the Good [[Shepherd]] who lays down his life for his [[sheep]]. Similar imagery is used in [[Psalm 23]]. The Good Shepherd is also discussed in the other gospels, the [[Epistle to the Hebrews]], the [[First Epistle of Peter]] and the [[Book of Revelation]].
==Biblical references== In the [[Gospel of John]], Jesus states "I am the good shepherd" in two verses, {{bibleverse||John|10:11|NIV}} and {{bibleverse-nb||John|10:14|NIV}}.
From {{bibleref|John|10:11-18}} ([[World Hindi Bible|WEB]]):
{{quote|I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. He who is a hired hand, and not a shepherd, who doesn't own the sheep, sees the wolf coming, leaves the sheep, and flees. The wolf snatches the sheep, and scatters them. The hired hand flees because he is a hired hand, and doesn't care for the sheep. I am the good shepherd. I know my own, and I'm known by my own; even as the Father knows me, and I know the Father. I lay down my life for the sheep. I have other sheep, which are not of this fold. I must bring them also, and they will hear my voice. They will become one flock with one shepherd. Therefore the Father loves me, because I lay down my life, that I may take it again. No one takes it away from me, but I lay it down by myself. I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again. I received this commandment from my Father.}}
This passage is one of several sections of John's Gospel which generate division among the Jews: :"There was a division again among the Jews because of these sayings. Many of them said, 'He has a demon and is mad. Why do you listen to Him?' Others said, 'These are not the words of one who has a demon'. ({{bibleverse||John|10:19-21|NKJV}})
[[File:Good shepherd 02b close.jpg|thumb|[[Allegory]] of Christ <ref>"The figure (...) is an allegory of Christ as the shepherd" Andre Grabard, "Christian iconography, a study of its origins", {{ISBN|0-691-01830-8}}</ref> as the [[The Good Shepherd (Christianity)|Good Shepherd]], 3rd century.]] Jesus Christ is also compared to a shepherd in {{bibleverse||Matthew|2:6|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Matthew|9:36|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Matthew|25:32|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Matthew|26:31|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Mark|6:34|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Mark|14:27|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||John|10:2|NIV}}, {{bibleverse||Hebrews|13:20|NIV}}, {{bibleverse|1|Peter|2:25|NIV}}, {{bibleverse|1|Peter|5:4|NIV}}, and {{bibleverse||Revelation|7:17|NIV}}.
==Parable or metaphor?== Several authors such as Tinto, Barbara Reid, Arland Hultgren or Donald Griggs comment that "parables are noticeably absent from the Gospel of John".<ref>Barbara Reid, 2001 ''Parables for Preachers'' {{ISBN|0-8146-2550-9}} page 3</ref><ref>Arland J. Hultgren, 2002 ''The Parables of Jesus'' {{ISBN|0-8028-6077-X}} page 2</ref><ref>Donald L. Griggs, 2003 ''The Bible from scratch'' {{ISBN|0-664-22577-2}} page 52</ref> According to the ''[[Catholic Encyclopedia]]'' article on Parables:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11460a.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Parables|publisher=}}</ref> "There are no [[parables]] in St. John's Gospel" and according to the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' article on Gospel of St. John:<ref>{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=John, Gospel of St |volume=15 |pages=452–458 |first=Friedrich |last=von Hügel}}</ref> "Here Jesus' teaching contains no parables and but three allegories, the [[Synoptic Gospels|Synoptists]] present it as parabolic through and through."
==Early Christian art== The image of the Good Shepherd is the most common of the symbolic [[Depiction of Jesus|representations of Christ]] found in [[early Christian art]] in the [[Catacombs of Rome]], before Christian imagery could be made explicit. The form of the image showing a young man carrying a lamb round his neck was directly borrowed from the much older pagan [[kriophoros]] (see below) and in the case of portable statuettes like the most famous one now in the [[Pio Cristiano Museum]], [[Vatican City]] (right), it is impossible to say whether the image was originally created with the intention of having a Christian significance. The image continued to be used in the centuries after Christianity was [[Edict of Milan|legalized in 313]]. Initially it was probably not understood as a portrait of Jesus, but a symbol like others used in Early Christian art,<ref>Eduard Syndicus; ''Early Christian Art''; pp. 21-3, Burns & Oates, London, 1962</ref> and in some cases may also have represented [[the Shepherd of Hermas]], a popular Christian literary work of the 2nd century.<ref>''The Two Faces of Jesus'' by Robin M. Jensen, ''Bible Review'', 17.8, October 2002</ref><ref>''Understanding Early Christian Art'' by Robin M. Jensen, Routledge, 2000</ref> However, by about the 5th century, the figure more often took on the appearance of the conventional depiction of Christ, as it had developed by this time, and was given a [[halo (religious iconography)|halo]] and rich robes,<ref>Syndicus, 130-131</ref> as on the [[apse]] [[mosaic]] in the church of [[Santi Cosma e Damiano]] in Rome, or at [[Ravenna]] (right). Images of the Good Shepherd often include a sheep on his shoulders, as in the Lukan version of the [[Parable of the Lost Sheep]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Walter |last=Lowrie |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0fwCGTzbMQ0C&pg=PA69 |title=Art in the Early Church |publisher= Pantheon Books|year= 1947 |isbn= 1-4067-5291-6|page= 69}}</ref>
== Pagan symbolism == {{main|Kriophoros}} [[File:Hermes crioforo.jpg|thumb|upright|Late Roman marble copy of the ''[[Kriophoros]]'' of [[Calamis (5th century BC)|Kalamis]] ([[Museo Barracco]], Rome)]]
In ancient Greek cult, [[kriophoros]] or ''criophorus'' (Κριοφόρος), the "ram-bearer" is a figure that commemorates the solemn sacrifice of a [[Sheep|ram]]. It becomes an [[epithet]] of [[Hermes]]: ''Hermes Kriophoros''.
In two-dimensional art, ''Hermes Kriophoros'' transformed into the Christ carrying a lamb and walking among his sheep: "Thus we find philosophers holding scrolls or a Hermes Kriophoros which can be turned into Christ giving the Law ([[Traditio Legis]]) and the Good Shepherd respectively".<ref>Peter and Linda Murray, ''The Oxford Companion to Classical Art and architecture'', p. 475.</ref> The Good Shepherd is a common motif from the [[Catacombs of Rome]] (Gardner, 10, fig 54) and in [[sarcophagus]] reliefs, where Christian and pagan symbolism are often combined, making secure identifications difficult.
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Good shepherd 01 small.jpg|At the [[Catacomb of Priscilla]], Rome File:Good shepherd.JPG|Fourth-century depiction at the Museum of the [[Baths of Diocletian]], Rome File:"The good Shepherd" mosaic - Mausoleum of Galla Placidia.jpg|[[Mausoleum of Galla Placidia#Good Shepherd Mosaic|Mosaic in the Mausoleum of Galla Placidia]], Ravenna, Italy, [[ca.]] 425 File:1750 Christus als Guter Hirte Niederbayern anagoria.JPG|Christ as the Good Shepherd, unknown artist from Lower Bavaria, 1750 File:The_Lord_is_my_Good_Shepherd.jpg|19th century by German Artist Bernard Plockhorst File:StJohnsAshfield StainedGlass GoodShepherd Portrait.jpg|20th-century [[stained glass]] depiction, Australia File:Emblem of the Catechism of the Catholic Church.jpg|Emblem of the Catechism of the Catholic Church File:Oratorio-pastor.jpg|Oratorio de la Santa Cueva. Cádiz, España </gallery>
==See also== {{Div col}} * [[Depictions of Jesus]] * [[I am (biblical term)]] * [[Names and titles of Jesus in the New Testament]] * [[Parable of the Lost Sheep]] * [[The Sheep and Goats]] * [[Mausoleum of Galla Placidia]] {{Div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category-inline|Jesus Christ as the Good Shepherd|Good Shepherd}} *[https://www.studylight.org/dictionaries/hbd/s/shepherd.html?hilite=shepherd Holman Bible Dictionary - "Shepherd"] for other Biblical references.
{{Jesus footer}} {{Parables of Jesus|state=expanded}}

revision.comment: Undid revision 863792953 by [[Special:Contributions/2605:A000:C753:5A00:A8AF:767E:F9CA:6DF4|2605:A000:C753:5A00:A8AF:767E:F9CA:6DF4]] ([[User talk:2605:A000:C753:5A00:A8AF:767E:F9CA:6DF4|talk]]) - stay consistent throughout article
revision.text:
{{redirect|Pearlescent|the type of paint|Pearlescent coating}} {{redirect|Iridescent|the Linkin Park song|Iridescent (song)}} {{for|the Brockhampton album|Iridescence (album)}} {{use British English|date=February 2014}} [[File:Soap Bubble - foliage background - iridescent colours - Traquair 040801.jpg|thumb|right|Iridescence in [[soap bubble]]s]]
'''Iridescence''' (also known as '''goniochromism''') is the phenomenon of certain surfaces that appear to [[Gradient|gradually]] change [[colour]] as the angle of view or the angle of illumination changes. Examples of iridescence include [[soap bubble]]s, [[butterfly]] wings and [[seashell]]s, as well as certain minerals. It is often created by [[structural coloration]] (microstructures that interfere with light).
'''Pearlescence''' is a related effect where some or all of the reflected light is white, where iridescent effects produce only other colours. The term pearlescent is used to describe certain paint finishes, usually in the automotive industry, which actually produce iridescent effects.
== Etymology == The word ''iridescence'' is derived in part from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word ἶρις ''îris'' ([[Genitive|gen.]] ἴριδος ''íridos''), meaning ''[[rainbow]]'', and is combined with the Latin suffix ''-escent'', meaning "having a tendency toward".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=-escent|title=Online Etymology Dictionary|work=etymonline.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407103248/http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=-escent|archivedate=2014-04-07|df=}}</ref> Iris in turn derives from the goddess [[Iris (mythology)|Iris]] of [[Greek mythology]], who is the personification of the [[rainbow]] and acted as a messenger of the gods. ''Goniochromism'' is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] words ''gonia'', meaning "angle", and ''chroma'', meaning "colour".
== Mechanisms == [[File:Dieselrainbow.jpg|thumb|Fuel on top of water creates a thin film, which interferes with the light, producing different colours. The different bands represent different thicknesses in the film.]] [[File:Iridescent biofilm on a fishtank.JPG|thumb|An iridescent [[biofilm]] on the surface of a fishtank diffracts the reflected light, displaying the entire spectrum of colours. Red is seen from longer angles of incidence than blue.]] {{further|Structural coloration|thin-film interference|diffraction}}
Iridescence is an [[optical phenomenon]] of surfaces in which [[hue]] changes with the angle of observation and the angle of illumination.<ref name="srinivasarao">[http://mohan.mse.gatech.edu/publication/1999_Chem%20Rev_v99_p1935.pdf Nano-optics in the biological world: beetles, butterflies, birds and moths] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140909193931/http://mohan.mse.gatech.edu/publication/1999_Chem%20Rev_v99_p1935.pdf |date=2014-09-09 }} Srinivasarao, M. (1999) Chemical Reviews pp: 1935–1961</ref><ref>[http://www.iap.tuwien.ac.at/~GEBESHUBER/Structured-color-physics.pdf Physics of structural colours] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213072755/http://www.iap.tuwien.ac.at/~GEBESHUBER/Structured-color-physics.pdf |date=2015-02-13 }} Kinoshita, S. et al (2008) Rep. Prog. Phys. 71: 076401</ref> It is often caused by multiple reflections from two or more semi-transparent surfaces in which [[phase (waves)|phase shift]] and [[Interference (wave propagation)|interference]] of the reflections [[amplitude modulation|modulates]] the incidental [[light]] (by amplifying or attenuating some frequencies more than others).<ref name="srinivasarao" /><ref name="meadows">{{cite journal | author = Meadows M. | year = 2009 | title = Iridescence: views from many angles | url = http://171.66.127.193/content/6/Suppl_2/S107.full | journal = J. R. Soc. Interface | volume = 6 | issue = | pages = S107–S113 | doi = 10.1098/rsif.2009.0013.focus | display-authors = etal | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20150215180313/http://171.66.127.193/content/6/Suppl_2/S107.full | archivedate = 2015-02-15 | df = }}</ref> The thickness of the layers of the material determines the interference pattern. Iridescence can for example be due to [[thin-film interference]], the functional analogue of selective wavelength attenuation as seen with the [[Fabry–Pérot interferometer]], and can be seen in oil films on water and soap bubbles. Iridescence is also found in plants, animals and many other items. The range of colours of natural iridescent objects can be narrow, for example shifting between two or three colours as the viewing angle changes,<ref name="yoshioka">{{cite journal | author = Yoshioka S. | year = 2011 | title = Mechanism of variable structural colour in the neon tetra: quantitative evaluation of the Venetian blind model | url = http://rsif.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/8/54/56.long | journal = J. Roy. Soc. Interface | volume = 8 | issue = 54 | pages = 56–66 | doi = 10.1098/rsif.2010.0253 | display-authors = etal | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304035917/http://rsif.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/8/54/56.long | archivedate = 2016-03-04 | df = | pmc = 3024824 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Rutowski RL | year = 2005 | title = Pterin pigments amplify iridescent ultraviolet signal in males of the orange sulphur butterfly, Colias eurytheme | url = https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1560183/pdf/rspb20053216.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Proc. R. Soc. B | volume = 272 | issue = 1578 | pages = 2329–2335 | pmc = 1560183 | pmid = 16191648 | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2005.3216 | display-authors = etal | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171220224632/https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1560183/pdf/rspb20053216.pdf | archivedate = 2017-12-20 | df = }}</ref> or a wide range of colours can be observed.<ref name="saego">{{cite journal | author = Saego AE | year = 2009 | title = Gold bugs and beyond: a review of iridescence and structural colour mechanisms in beetles (Coleoptera) | url = http://171.66.127.193/content/6/Suppl_2/S165.full | journal = J. R. Soc. Interface | volume = 6 | issue = | pages = S165–S184 | display-authors = etal | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20150215180401/http://171.66.127.193/content/6/Suppl_2/S165.full | archivedate = 2015-02-15 | df = }}</ref>
Iridescence can also be created by [[diffraction]]. This is found in items like CDs, DVDs, some types of [[prism]]s, or [[cloud iridescence]].<ref>''Meteorology'' By Professor of Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences University of Wisconsin-Madison Director Cooperative Institute for Meteorological Satellite Studies (Cimss) Steven A Ackerman, Steven A. Ackerman, John A. Knox -- Jones and Bartlett Learning 2013 Page 173-175</ref> In the case of diffraction, the entire rainbow of colours will typically be observed as the viewing angle changes. In biology, this type of iridescence results from the formation of [[diffraction grating]]s on the surface, such as the long rows of cells in [[striated muscle]], or the specialized abdominal scales of peacock spider ''Maratus robinsoni'' and ''M. chrysomelas''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hsiung|first=Bor-Kai|last2=Siddique|first2=Radwanul Hasan|last3=Stavenga|first3=Doekele G.|last4=Otto|first4=Jürgen C.|last5=Allen|first5=Michael C.|last6=Liu|first6=Ying|last7=Lu|first7=Yong-Feng|last8=Deheyn|first8=Dimitri D.|last9=Shawkey|first9=Matthew D.|date=2017-12-22|title=Rainbow peacock spiders inspire miniature super-iridescent optics|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-017-02451-x|journal=Nature Communications|language=En|volume=8|issue=|pages=2278|doi=10.1038/s41467-017-02451-x|issn=2041-1723|via=}}</ref> Some types of flower petals can also generate a diffraction grating, but the iridescence is not visible to humans and flower-visiting insects as the diffraction signal is masked by the coloration due to [[plant pigments]].<ref>Nature's palette: the science of plant colour. Lee, DW (2007) University of Chicago Press</ref><ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/261515138 Iridescent flowers? Contribution of surface structures to optical signaling] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160924091947/https://www.researchgate.net/publication/261515138 |date=2016-09-24 }} van der Kooi, CJ et al (2014) New Phytol 203: 667–673</ref><ref>[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/265912479 Is floral iridescence a biologically relevant cue in plant–pollinator signaling?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170305003451/https://www.researchgate.net/publication/265912479 |date=2017-03-05 }} van der Kooi, CJ et al (2015) New Phytol 205: 18–20</ref>
In biological (and [[biomimetic]]) uses, colours produced other than with [[pigment]]s or [[dye]]s are called [[structural coloration]]<!-- -or- is UK spelling here -->. Microstructures, often multilayered, are used to produce bright but sometimes non-iridescent colours: quite elaborate arrangements are needed to avoid reflecting different colours in different directions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hsiung|first=Bor-Kai|last2=Siddique|first2=Radwanul Hasan|last3=Jiang|first3=Lijia|last4=Liu|first4=Ying|last5=Lu|first5=Yongfeng|last6=Shawkey|first6=Matthew D.|last7=Blackledge|first7=Todd A.|date=2017-01-15|title=Tarantula-Inspired Noniridescent Photonics with Long-Range Order|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/adom.201600599/abstract|journal=Advanced Optical Materials|language=en|volume=5|issue=2|pages=1600599|doi=10.1002/adom.201600599|issn=2195-1071|via=}}</ref> Structural coloration has been understood in general terms since [[Robert Hooke]]'s 1665 book ''[[Micrographia]]'', where Hooke correctly noted that since the iridescence of a [[peacock]]'s feather was lost when it was plunged into water, but reappeared when it was returned to the air, pigments could not be responsible.<ref name=HookeOnPeacockIridescence>Hooke, Robert. Micrographia. Chapter 36 ('Observ. XXXVI. ''Of Peacoks, Ducks, and Other Feathers of Changeable Colours''.')</ref><ref name=Ball>{{cite journal | url=http://www.nature.com/scientificamerican/journal/v306/n5/full/scientificamerican0512-74.html | journal=Scientific American | title=Nature's Color Tricks | date=May 2012 | accessdate=April 23, 2012 | author=Ball, Philip | volume=306 | pages=74–79 | doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0512-74 | pmid=22550931 | issue=5 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711120040/http://www.nature.com/scientificamerican/journal/v306/n5/full/scientificamerican0512-74.html | archivedate=July 11, 2014 | df= }}</ref> It was later found that iridescence in the peacock is due to a complex [[photonic crystal]].<ref name="peacock">{{cite journal | author = Zi J | year = 2003 | title = Coloration strategies in peacock feathers | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/100/22/12576.full | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. | volume = 100 | issue = 22 | pages = 12576–12578 | display-authors = etal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.2133313100 | pmid = 14557541 | pmc = 240659 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150924134204/http://www.pnas.org/content/100/22/12576.full | archivedate = 2015-09-24 | df = }}</ref>
==Pearlescence== Pearlescence is an effect related to iridescence and has a similar cause. Structures within a surface cause light to be reflected back, but in the case of pearlescence some or all of the light is white.<ref name=pearleasence>{{cite book|author=Ruth Johnston-Feller|title=Color Science in the Examination of Museum Objects: Nondestructive Procedures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HtoxCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA169|year=2001|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-586-9|pages=169–}}</ref> Artificial pigments and paints showing an iridescent effect are often described as pearlescent, for example when used for [[car paint]]s.<ref name=paint>{{cite book|title=Paint and Coating Testing Manual|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ri6FkY2xvgcC&pg=PA229|publisher=ASTM International|pages=229–|id=GGKEY:7W7C2G88G2J}}</ref>
== Examples == === Life === ==== Arthropods and molluscs ====
<gallery class="center"> File:Female Golden Stag Beetle.jpg|The iridescent exoskeleton of a golden [[stag beetle]] File:Morpho didius Male Dos MHNT.jpg|[[Structural coloration|Structurally coloured]] wings of ''[[Morpho didius]]'' File:Haliotis iris LC0283.jpg|The inside surface of ''[[Haliotis iris]]'', the paua shell File:Tachinidae.jpg|Structurally coloured wings of a [[Tachinid fly]] </gallery>
==== Chordates ==== The [[feather]]s of birds such as [[kingfisher]]s,<ref>{{cite journal | author = Stavenga D.G. | year = 2011 | title = Kingfisher feathers – colouration by pigments, spongy nanostructures and thin films | url = http://jeb.biologists.org/content/214/23/3960.full | journal = J. Exp. Biol. | volume = 214 | issue = 23 | pages = 3960–3967 | doi = 10.1242/jeb.062620 | display-authors = etal | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140811051027/http://jeb.biologists.org/content/214/23/3960.full | archivedate = 2014-08-11 | df = }}</ref> [[Birds-of-paradise]],<ref>{{cite journal | author = Stavenga D.G. | year = 2010 | title = Dramatic colour changes in a bird of paradise caused by uniquely structured breast feather barbules | url = http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/royprsb/early/2010/12/11/rspb.2010.2293.full.pdf | format = PDF | journal = Proc. R. Soc. B | volume = 278 | issue = 1715 | pages = 2098–2104 | doi = 10.1098/rspb.2010.2293 | display-authors = etal | pmid = 21159676 | pmc = 3107630 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160304034954/http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/royprsb/early/2010/12/11/rspb.2010.2293.full.pdf | archivedate = 2016-03-04 | df = }}</ref> [[hummingbird]]s, [[parrot]]s, [[starling]]s,<ref>Plumage Reflectance and the Objective Assessment of Avian Sexual Dichromatism Cuthill, I.C. et al. (1999) Am. Nat. 153: 183-200 {{JSTOR|303160}}</ref> [[grackle]]s, [[duck]]s, and [[peacock]]s<ref name ="peacock" /> are iridescent. The lateral line on the [[Neon tetra]] is also iridescent.<ref name="yoshioka" /> A single iridescent species of gecko, ''[[Cnemaspis kolhapurensis]]'', was identified in India in 2009.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/8166904.stm |title=New lizard species found in India|date=24 July 2009 |work=[[BBC Online]] |accessdate=20 February 2014}}</ref> The [[tapetum lucidum]], present in the [[eye]]s of many vertebrates, is also iridescent.<ref>{{cite book |last=Engelking|first=Larry |title=Review of Veterinary Physiology|year=2002 |publisher=Teton NewMedia |isbn=1-893441-69-5 |page=90}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Peacock 2.jpg|Both the body and the train of the peacock are iridescent File:Iridescent Shark Catfish.jpg|A [[catfish]] File:Rainbow boa peruvian.jpg|The [[rainbow boa]] File:Nicobar Pigeon 820.jpg|[[Nicobar pigeon]] </gallery>
==== Plants ==== [[File:Iridescent_begonia.jpg|thumb|Iridescent ''[[Begonia]]'' leaf]]
Many groups of plants have developed iridescence as an adaptation to use more light in dark environments such as the lower levels of tropical forests. The leaves of Southeast Asia's ''Begonia pavonina'', or peacock begonia, appear iridescent azure to human observers due to each leaf's thinly layered photosynthetic structures called iridoplasts that absorb and bend light much like a film of oil over water. Iridescences based on multiple layers of cells are also found in the lycophyte ''[[Selaginella]]'' and several species of ferns.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Glover |first=Beverley J. |last2=Whitney |first2=Heather M. |date=April 2010 |title=Structural colour and iridescence in plants: the poorly studied relations of pigment colour |url=https://academic.oup.com/aob/article/105/4/505/190572 |journal=Annals of Botany |volume=105 |issue=4 |pages=505–511 |doi=10.1093/aob/mcq007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171116202157/https://academic.oup.com/aob/article/105/4/505/190572 |archivedate=2017-11-16 |df= |pmc=2850791 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Graham |first=Rita M. |last2=Lee |first2=David W. |last3=Norstog |first3=Knut |date=1993 |title=Physical and Ultrastructural Basis of Blue Leaf Iridescence in Two Neotropical Ferns |jstor=2445040 |journal=American Journal of Botany |volume=80 |issue=2 |pages=198–203 |doi=10.2307/2445040 }}</ref>
==== Meat ==== <gallery class="center"> File:Meat Iridiscence.png|Iridescence in meat, caused by light [[diffraction]] on the exposed muscle cells<ref name="Martinez-HurtadoAkram2013">{{cite journal |last1=Martinez-Hurtado |first1=Juan |last2=Akram |first2=Muhammad |last3=Yetisen |first3=Ali |title=Iridescence in Meat Caused by Surface Gratings |journal=Foods |volume=2 |issue=4 |year=2013 |pages=499–506 |doi=10.3390/foods2040499}}</ref> </gallery>
=== Minerals and compounds === <gallery class="center"> File:IridescentAmmonite.jpg|An [[ammolite]] gemstone is a fossil [[ammonite]]. File:Wismut Kristall und 1cm3 Wuerfel.jpg|A [[bismuth]] crystal with a thin iridescent layer of [[bismuth oxide]] File:Goethite-171990.jpg|[[Goethite]], an [[iron(III) oxide-hydroxide]], from [[Polk County, Arkansas]] File:Rainbow_Pyrite.jpg|[[Rainbow Pyrite|Rainbow pyrite]], a variety of mineral [[Iron pyrite#Varieties|pyrite]]. The iridescence is caused by tarnishing by oxidation and molybdenum traces in the mineral. File:Engine oil rainbow p1120058.jpg|An [[engine oil]] spill File:Irid clouds1.jpg|[[Cloud iridescence]] </gallery>
=== Man-made objects === <gallery class="center" mode="packed"> File:Pearlescent Toyota Supra - 002.jpg|[[Pearlescent paint]] job on a Toyota Supra car File:CD-ROM.png|Playing surface of a [[compact disc]] File:Glitter nail polish %28purple%29.jpg|iridescent [[glitter]] [[nail polish]] </gallery>
[[Nanocellulose]] is sometimes iridescent,<ref name="PicardSimon2012">{{cite journal|last1=Picard|first1=G.|last2=Simon|first2=D.|last3=Kadiri|first3=Y.|last4=LeBreux|first4=J. D.|last5=Ghozayel|first5=F.|title=Cellulose Nanocrystal Iridescence: A New Model|journal=Langmuir|volume=28|issue=41|year=2012|pages=14799–14807|doi=10.1021/la302982s}}</ref> as are thin films of [[gasoline]] and some other [[hydrocarbon]]s and [[alcohol]]s when floating on water.<ref>{{cite book|last=Zitzewitz|first=Paul W|title=The Handy Physics Answer Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qGTkgFZBJZQC&pg=PA215|year=2011|publisher=Visible Ink Press|isbn=978-1-57859-357-6|page=215}}</ref>
To create jewelry with crystal glass that lets light refract in a rainbow spectrum, [[Swarovski]] coats some of its products with special metallic chemical coatings and for example, [[Aurora]] Borealis, or "AB", gives the surface a rainbow appearance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Decorations Christmas Star Ornament, Crystal AB|url=https://www.swarovski.com/Web_GB/en/5283480/product/Star_Ornament,_Crystal_AB.html|publisher=[[Svarovski]]|accessdate=23 March 2018|quote=This stunning star ornament will add a captivating, iridescent sparkle to your holiday décor. It is coated with Swarovski’s Aurora Borealis effect, which is named after the Northern Lights and makes the crystal shimmer magically in every colour of the rainbow.}}</ref> Rainbow [[anodizing]] is also possible.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rainbow effect / defect on anodized aluminum?|url=https://www.finishing.com/565/81.shtml|publisher=Finishing.com|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
Iridescent products in the cosmetic and clothing industries are often referred as being [[holographic]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Out of This World: How to Pull Off the Holographic Makeup Trend|url=https://www.lorealparisusa.com/beauty-magazine/makeup/makeup-trends/how-to-do-holographic-makeup.aspx|publisher=[[L'Oreal]]|accessdate=23 March 2018|quote=Also known as galaxy makeup, holographic makeup is all about rocking iridescent shades all over your face}}</ref>

page.title: Johnny Panic and the Bible of Dreams

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{for|the song by Tears for Fears|Johnny Panic and the Bible of Dreams (song)}} [[File:JohnnyPanic.jpg|thumb|First edition (publ. [[Faber and Faber]])]] '''''Johnny Panic and the Bible of Dreams''''' is a collection of short stories by [[Sylvia Plath]]. It was [[wikt:Special:Search/posthumous|posthumously]] published in 1977 as a collection of thirteen short stories, including the title story.
As more of Plath's work was unearthed down the years, a second edition was published with many new stories. The second edition is split into four parts, and includes many new stories, some of which were very personal to Plath. As Plath's husband at the time of her death in 1963, fellow poet and writer [[Ted Hughes]] managed the publication and distribution of all her unpublished works, including her poetry.
The English Band [[Tears for Fears]] has [[Johnny Panic and the Bible of Dreams (song)|a song named after this work]]. {{Sylvia Plath}}
[[Category:1977 short story collections]] [[Category:Single-writer short story collections]] [[Category:American short story collections]] [[Category:Books by Sylvia Plath]] [[Category:Books published posthumously]] [[Category:Faber and Faber books]]

{{for|the album by Les Breastfeeders|Déjeuner sur l'herbe (album)}} {{for|the 1979 Soviet musical film|The Luncheon on the Grass (film)}} {{for|the painting by Claude Monet|Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe (Monet)}} {{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Edouard Manet - Luncheon on the Grass - Google Art Project.jpg | image_size=350px | title=The Luncheon on the Grass | other_language_1=French | other_title_1=Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe | artist=[[Édouard Manet]] | year=1863 | medium=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric=208 | width_metric=264.5 | height_imperial=81.9 | width_imperial=104.1 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Paris]] | museum=[[Musée d'Orsay]] }} '''''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe''''' ([[English language|English]]: ''The Luncheon on the Grass'') – originally titled '''''Le Bain''''' (''The Bath'') – is a large [[oil on canvas]] painting by [[Édouard Manet]] created in 1862 and 1863. It depicts a [[female nude]] and a scantily dressed female bather on a picnic with two fully dressed men in a rural setting. Rejected by the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon]] jury of 1863, Manet seized the opportunity to exhibit this and two other paintings in the 1863 [[Salon des Refusés]],[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k114147v Catalogue des ouvrages de peinture, sculpture, gravure, lithographie et architecture : refusés par le Jury de 1863 et exposés, par décision de S.M. l'Empereur au salon annexe, palais des Champs-Elysées, le 15 mai 1863, Édouard Manet, ''Le Bain'', no. 363], Bibliothèque nationale de France where the painting sparked public notoriety and controversy.{{cite book|last=Boime|first=Albert|title=Art in an Age of Civil Struggle|year=2007|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|location=Los Angeles|isbn=978-0-226-06328-7|pages=676}} The piece is now in the [[Musée d'Orsay]] in [[Paris]].[http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/works-in-focus/search/commentaire_id/le-dejeuner-sur-lherbe-7123.html?no_cache=1&cHash=48427e6bdb Musée d'Orsay, Le déjeuner sur l'herbe (Luncheon on the Grass)] A smaller, earlier version can be seen at the [[Courtauld Institute of Art#The Courtauld Gallery|Courtauld Gallery]], [[London]].[http://www.artandarchitecture.org.uk/images/gallery/2454912b.html The Courtauld Gallery version] ==Description and context== The painting features a nude woman casually lunching with two fully dressed men. Her body is starkly lit and she stares directly at the viewer. The two men, dressed as young [[dandy|dandies]], seem to be engaged in conversation, ignoring the woman. In front of them, the woman's clothes, a basket of fruit, and a round loaf of bread are displayed, as in a [[still life]]. In the background, a lightly clad woman bathes in a stream. Too large in comparison with the figures in the foreground, she seems to float above them. The roughly painted background lacks depth, giving the viewer the impression that the scene is not taking place outdoors, but in a studio. This impression is reinforced by the use of broad "studio" light, which casts almost no shadows. The man on the right wears a flat hat with a tassel, a kind normally worn indoors. Despite the mundane subject, Manet deliberately chose a large canvas size, measuring 81.9 x 104.1 in (208 by 264.5 cm), normally reserved for historical, religious, and mythological subjects.{{cite book|last1=Tucker|first1=Paul Hayes|title=Manet's Le Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe|date=1998|publisher=Cambridge UP|location=Cambridge|pages=5–14}} The style of the painting breaks with the academic traditions of the time. He did not try to hide the brush strokes; the painting even looks unfinished in some parts of the scene. The nude is also starkly different from the smooth, flawless figures of [[Alexandre Cabanel|Cabanel]] or [[Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres|Ingres]]. A nude woman casually lunching with fully dressed men was an affront to audiences' sense of propriety, though [[Émile Zola]], a contemporary of Manet's, argued that this was not uncommon in paintings found in the [[Louvre]]. Zola also felt that such a reaction came from viewing art differently than "analytic" painters like Manet, who use a painting's subject as a pretext to paint. There is much still not known about the painting, such as when Manet actually began painting it, exactly how he got the idea, and how and what sort of preparation works he did. Though Manet had claimed this piece was once valued at 25,000 Francs in 1871, it actually remained in his possession until 1878 when [[Jean-Baptiste Faure]], opera-singer and collector, bought it for just 2,600 Francs. ==Figures in the painting== The figures of this painting are a testament to how deeply connected Manet was to ''Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe''. Some assume that the landscape of the painting is meant to be [[L'Île-Saint-Denis|l’île Saint-Ouen]], which was just up [[the Seine]] from his family property in [[Gennevilliers]]. Manet often used real models and people he knew as reference during his creation process.{{cite book|last1=Armstrong|first1=Carol|title="To Paint, To Point, To Pose" Manet's Le Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe|date=1998|publisher=Cambridge UP|location=Cambridge|pages=93–111}} The female nude is thought to be [[Victorine Meurent]], the woman who became his favorite and frequently portrayed model, who later was the subject of [[Olympia (Manet)|''Olympia'']]. The male figure on the right was based on a combination of his two brothers, Eugène and Gustave Manet. The other man is based on his brother-in-law, Dutch sculptor {{ill|Ferdinand Leenhoff|fr}}. Nancy Locke referred to this scene as Manet’s family portrait. ==Interactions of the figures== What many critics find shocking about this painting is the interaction, or lack thereof, between the three main subjects in the foreground and the woman bathing in the background. There are many contrasting qualities to the painting that juxtapose and distance the female nude from the other two male subjects. For example, the feminine versus the masculine, the naked versus the clothed, and the white color palette versus the dark color palette creates a clear social difference between the men and the woman. Additionally, some viewers are intrigued by the questions raised by the gaze of the nude woman. It is indeterminable whether she is challenging or accepting the viewer, looking past the viewer, engaging the viewer, or even looking at the viewer at all. This encounter identifies the gaze as a figure of the painting itself, as well as the figure object of the woman’s gaze. ==Inspirations== As with the later ''[[Olympia (Manet)|Olympia]]'' (1863) and other works, Manet's composition reveals his study of the old masters, as the disposition of the main figures is derived from [[Marcantonio Raimondi]]'s engraving ''The Judgment of Paris'' (c. 1515) after a drawing by [[Raphael]].Ross King. ''The Judgement of Paris: The Revolutionary Decade that Gave the World Impressionism''. New York: Waller & Company, 2006 {{ISBN|0-8027-1466-8}}. Raphael was an artist revered by the conservative members of the [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]] and his paintings were part of the teaching programme at the [[École des Beaux-Arts]], where copies of fifty-two images from his most celebrated frescoes were permanently on display. ''Le Bain'' (an early title for ''Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe'') was therefore, in many ways, a defiant painting. Manet was cheekily reworking Raphael, turning a mythological scene from one of the most celebrated engravings of the [[Renaissance]] into a tableau of somewhat vulgar Parisian holidaymakers.Ross King, p. 41. File:Urteil des Paris.jpg|''Judgement of Paris'' [[Engraving]] (ca. 1515) by [[Marcantonio Raimondi]] to a design by [[Raphael]] File:Fiesta campestre.jpg|''[[The Pastoral Concert]]'' (ca. 1510) by [[Giorgione]] or [[Titian]], [[Louvre]], Paris, cited as an inspiration for Manet's painting File:Giorgione, The tempest.jpg|[[Giorgione]], ''[[The Tempest (painting)|The Tempest]]'' (c. 1508), Gallerie dell'Accademia, Venice, Italy File:Antoine Watteau - La Partie carrée.jpg|[[Antoine Watteau]], ''La Partie Carrée,'' (c. 1713) Scholars also cite two works as important precedents for Manet's painting ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe'': ''The Pastoral Concert'' by [[Giorgione]] or possibly [[Titian]] (in the [[Louvre]]) and Giorgione's [[The Tempest (painting)|''The Tempest'']], both of which are famous [[Renaissance]] paintings. ''The Tempest'', which also features a fully dressed man and a nude woman in a rural setting, offers an important precedent for Manet's painting ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe.''[[John Rewald]],''The History of Impressionism'', [[The Museum of Modern Art]], 4th revised edition 1973, (1st 1946, 2nd 1955, 3rd 1961), p. 85. {{ISBN|0-87070-369-2}}. ''Pastoral Concert'' even more closely resembles ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe,'' as it features two dressed men seated in a rural setting, with two undressed women. ''Pastoral Concert'' is in the collection of the [[Louvre]] in [[Paris]] and is likely, therefore, to have been studied by Manet. According to Proust, he and Manet had been lounging by the Seine as they spotted a woman bathing in the river. This prompted Manet to say, "I copied Giorgione’s women, the women with musicians. It’s black that painting. The ground has come through. I want to redo it and do it with a transparent atmosphere with people like those we see over there."{{cite journal|last1=Laessøe|first1=Rolf|title=Édouard Manet's "Le Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe" as a Veiled Allegory of Painting|journal=Artibus et Historiae|date=2005|volume=26|issue=51|page=197}} There may be a connection between ''Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe'' and the work of [[Jean Antoine Watteau]].{{cite book|last1=Fried|first1=Michael|title=Manet's Modernism or, The Face of Painting in the 1860s|date=1996|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago|pages=56–57}} Manet’s original title, ''Le Bain'', initially drew the main attention to the woman near the water. This bathing figure alone is quite similar to the figure in Watteau’s ''Le Villageoise'', as both women crouch or lean over near water, simultaneously holding up their skirts. It’s possible that Manet adapted this pose, which is more clearly seen in a sketch of his years before his creation of ''Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe''. ==Critique and controversy== There were many mixed reviews and responses to ''Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe'' when it was first displayed[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k108159t Fernand Desnoyers, ''La peinture en 1863 : Salon des refusés'', A. Dutil (Paris) 1863], Bibliothèque nationale de France (in French) and it continues to yield a variety of responses. The initial response was characterized by its blunt rejection from the Paris Salon and subsequent display in the [[Salon des Refusés]]. Though many critiques were rooted in confusion about the piece, they were not always completely negative.{{cite book|last1=McCauley|first1=Anne|title="Sex and the Salon" Manet's Le Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe|date=1998|publisher=Cambridge UP|location=Cambridge|pages=41–44}} * [[Odilon Redon]], for example, did not like it. There is a discussion of it, from this point of view, in [[Proust]]'s ''[[Remembrance of Things Past]]''. * [[Le Capitaine Pompilius]], a contributor for ''[[Le Petit Journal (newspaper)|Le Petit Journal]]'', thought the characteristically "male" colors of the piece brought the countryside into the salon, but thought the painting was underdeveloped. * [[Jules-Antoine Castagnary|Castagnary]], appreciator of realist works, identified it as a nice sketch but said it lacked sincerity and lost the definition of the anatomy of the subjects. He also described Manet’s painting technique as "flabby". * Arthur Stevens, contributor for ''[[Le Figaro]]'', praised Manet as a talented colorist but felt that he neglected form and modeling in this piece. * [[Théophile Thoré-Bürger|Thoré]], Paul, and Louvet loved the energy of the colors but found the brush strokes to be uneven. One interpretation of the work is that it depicts the rampant prostitution present at that time in the [[Bois de Boulogne]], a large park on the western outskirts of Paris. This prostitution was common knowledge in Paris, but was considered a taboo subject unsuitable for a painting.Peter J. Gartner, ''Art and Architecture: Musée d'Orsay'', 2001, p. 180. {{ISBN|0-7607-2889-5}}. Indeed, the Bois de Boulogne is to this day known as a pick-up place for prostitutes and illicit sexual activity after dark, just as it had been in the 19th century. === Critiques of the subject matter === * Louis Étienne characterized the painting as a puzzle, while describing the nude female as "a Bréda of some sort, as nude as possible, lolling boldly between two swells dressed to the teeth. These two persons look like high school students on holiday, committing a great sin to prove their manhood."[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k1141487 Louis Étienne, ''Le jury et les exposants: salon des refusés'', Paris, 1863, p. 30.], Bibliothèque nationale de France * Arthur Stevens could not understand what the painting was saying. * Didier de Montchaux found the subject to be "fairly scabrous". * Thoré described the nude as an ugly and risqué subject matter, while describing the male on the right as one "who doesn’t even think of taking off his horrible padded hat outdoors…It’s the contrast between such an antipathetic animal to the character of a pastoral scene, and this undraped bather, that is shocking." * [[Philip Gilbert Hamerton|Philip Hamerton]], an English painter and contributor at the ''Fine Arts Quarterly'', had an affinity for the characteristic photographic detail of the [[Pre-Raphaelite]] paintings. Though he did recognize the inspiration from Giorgione, he found Manet’s modern realism to be offensive in this situation. His disapproval of Manet and similar artists was related to the idea of indecency behind "vulgar men" painting nude women. === General response === Though the peculiarity of the combination of one female nude with three clothed figures sparked mixed responses, the lack of interaction of the figures in addition to the lack of engagement by the nude woman provoked laughter instead of offense. Laughter as a response represses the sexual tension and makes the scene rather unthreatening to the viewer in the end. ==Commentary of Émile Zola==
''The Luncheon on the Grass'' is the greatest work of Édouard Manet, one in which he realizes the dream of all painters: to place figures of natural grandeur in a landscape. We know the power with which he vanquished this difficulty. There are some leaves, some tree trunks, and, in the background, a river in which a chemise-wearing woman bathes; in the foreground, two young men are seated across from a second woman who has just exited the water and who dries her naked skin in the open air. This nude woman has scandalized the public, who see only her in the canvas. My God! What indecency: a woman without the slightest covering between two clothed men! That has never been seen. And this belief is a gross error, for in the [[Louvre]] there are more than fifty paintings in which are found mixes of persons clothed and nude. But no one goes to the Louvre to be scandalized. The crowd has kept itself moreover from judging ''The Luncheon on the Grass'' like a veritable work of art should be judged; they see in it only some people who are having a picnic, finishing bathing, and they believed that the artist had placed an obscene intent in the disposition of the subject, while the artist had simply sought to obtain vibrant oppositions and a straightforward audience. Painters, especially Édouard Manet, who is an analytic painter, do not have this preoccupation with the subject which torments the crowd above all; the subject, for them, is merely a pretext to paint, while for the crowd, the subject alone exists. Thus, assuredly, the nude woman of ''The Luncheon on the Grass'' is only there to furnish the artist the occasion to paint a bit of flesh. That which must be seen in the painting is not a luncheon on the grass; it is the entire landscape, with its vigors and its finesses, with its foregrounds so large, so solid, and its backgrounds of a light delicateness; it is this firm modeled flesh under great spots of light, these tissues supple and strong, and particularly this delicious silhouette of a woman wearing a chemise who makes, in the background, an adorable dapple of white in the milieu of green leaves. It is, in short, this vast ensemble, full of atmosphere, this corner of nature rendered with a simplicity so just, all of this admirable page in which an artist has placed all the particular and rare elements which are in him.Émile Zola, ''Édouard Manet,'' 1867, et lps 91[https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://www.cahiers-naturalistes.com/Salons/01-01-67.html&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dzola%2Bon%2Bmanet%26start%3D10%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26hs%3Dpu9%26sa%3DN%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official%26channel%3Dsb%26biw%3D1799%26bih%3D840 Émile Zola, ''Édouard Manet,'' 1867, link to English translation]
Zola presents a fictionalised version of the painting and the controversy surrounding it in his novel ''[[L'Œuvre]]'' (''The Masterpiece''). == Inspired works== [[File:Monet dejeunersurlherbe.jpg|thumb|[[Claude Monet]], ''[[Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe (Monet)|Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe]]'', 1865–1866, [[Musée d'Orsay]], [[Paris, France|Paris]].]] [[File:James Tissot - La Partie carrée.jpg|thumb|left|[[James Tissot]], ''La Partie Carrée'', 1870]] * In ''L'Oeuvre'', Émile Zola's novel about a painter, a work by his main character, Claude Lantier, exhibited in a fictional salon des refusés, resembles Manet's painting. * [[Claude Monet]]'s own version of ''[[Le Déjeuner sur l’herbe (Monet)|Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe]]'' from 1865–1866, was inspired by Manet's masterpiece. * French painter [[James Tissot]], painted ''La Partie Carrée'', in 1870; arguably a tamer version without the nudity of ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe''. * [[Paul Cézanne]] painted the same theme in his ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe'' (1876–1877), [[Musée de l'Orangerie]], Paris. It is not certain, however, that Cézanne was responsible for the title of the work, but it does incorporate many of the same elements of subject in the piece. For example, Cézanne’s clothed female subject poses similarly to the model of Manet in which her chin rests in her hand. The male figure, meant to resemble the painter himself, mimics the hand gesture of the man furthest right in Manet’s piece.{{cite book|last1=Locke|first1=Nancy|title="Le Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe as a Family Romance" Manet's Le Déjeuner Sur L'Herbe|date=1998|publisher=Cambridge UP|location=Cambridge|page=121}} The composition of Cézanne's painting also bears resemblance to ''[[:File:Nicolas Poussin - Bacchanal - the Andrians - WGA18269.jpg|Bacchanal]]'' (between 1627 and 1628), by [[Nicolas Poussin]], whose works in the Louvre were periodically copied by Cézanne. It is possible that Cézanne's ''Déjeuner'' represents nothing more than the joyful memories of outings in the countryside around Aix-en-Provence, known especially from the testimony of a childhood friend of the painter, Émile Zola.[http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/pages/page_id19113_u1l2.htm Paul Cézanne, ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe'' (1876–1877), Musée de l'Orangerie, Paris] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141029032121/http://www.musee-orangerie.fr/pages/page_id19113_u1l2.htm |date=2014-10-29 }} * Manet’s painting inspired [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]] as he completed the largest concentration of art prompted by a single work during the 20th century, consisting of 27 paintings, 140 drawings, 3 linogravures and cardboard marquettes for sculpture carried out between 1949 and 1962.''Picasso: Challenging the past'' [[National Gallery (London)|National Gallery]] exhibition book, p. 116. Picasso also adopted some of Manet’s techniques involving exploitation of the nude in the foreground as evident in his work ''[[Les Demoiselles d'Avignon]]'', 1907. * [[Paul Gauguin]] may have been inspired by this piece in creating his 1896 work ''Where do we come from? Who are we? Where are we going?'', as there is a similarity of Manet’s depiction of the nude woman and Gauguin’s Tahitian woman. * [[Max Ernst]] painted a parody version of this piece named ''Le Déjeuner sur l'Herbre'' in 1944. He inverts the painting, replaces the nude woman with a fish, and adds an 'r' to the title for comedic effect.{{Cite web|url=http://www.clevelandart.org/art/2002.55?collection_search_query=fish&op=search&form_build_id=form-LSCVdx4K6pNGdu3UeD8aED5T32uXqJtj4kV67Am_FPk&form_id=clevelandart_collection_search_form&f%5B0%5D=object_on_view:1&c=1|title=Le Déjeuner sur l'Herbre {{!}} Cleveland Museum of Art|website=www.clevelandart.org|language=en|access-date=2018-01-13}} * The painting inspired the 1959 [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0052765/ film] of the same name by [[Jean Renoir]]. * It was copied in the cover photo of the [[Bow Wow Wow]] [[LP record|LP]] ''[[See Jungle! See Jungle! Go Join Your Gang Yeah, City All Over! Go Ape Crazy!]]'', and the [[extended play|EP]] ''[[The Last of the Mohicans (Bow Wow Wow EP)|The Last of the Mohicans]]''. Controversy arose because the naked girl (lead singer [[Annabella Lwin]]) was only 14 at the time. * [[Alain Jacquet]] copied in 1964 the composition of Manet in his ''Déjeuner sur l'herbe''[http://collection.centrepompidou.fr/#/artworks?layout=mosaic&page=0&filters=authors:JACQUET+Alain%E2%86%B9JACQUET+Alain :], a serie of 95 serigraphies portraying the art critic [[Pierre Restany]] and the painter [[Mario Schifano]], one of which was left in the lobby of the [[hotel Chelsea]] in [[New York City]] for payment of his room. File:Paul Cézanne - Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe (Orangerie).jpg|[[Paul Cézanne]], ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe'', 1876-1877, [[Musée de l'Orangerie]] File:Gauguin - Tahitianer 001.jpg|[[Paul Gauguin]], ''[[Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?]]'', 1897. (detail). File:Les Demoiselles d'Avignon.jpg|[[Pablo Picasso]], ''[[Les Demoiselles d'Avignon]]'', 1907, [[MoMA]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= | video1 = [http://smarthistory.khanacademy.org/edouard-manet-le-dejeuner-sur-lherbe.html Manet's ''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe''] at [[Smarthistory]].}} *{{Commons category-inline|Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe by Manet|''Le Déjeuner sur l'herbe'' by Manet}} *[http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/index-of-works/notice.html?no_cache=1&nnumid=904 ''Le déjeuner sur l'herbe (Luncheon on the Grass)'', Musée d'Orsay, Full entry] *[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/compoundobject/collection/p15324coll10/id/78705/rec/222 ''Impressionism: A Centenary Exhibition''], an exhibition catalog from The Metropolitan Museum of Art (fully available online as PDF), which contains material on this painting (pp. 131–134) {{Manet|state=expanded}} {{Modernism}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dejeuner Sur L'Herbe}} [[Category:1863 paintings]] [[Category:Collection of the Courtauld Institute of Art]] [[Category:Collections of the Musée d'Orsay]] [[Category:Nude art]] [[Category:Paintings by Édouard Manet]] [[Category:Art works that caused riots]] [[Category:Food and drink paintings]] [[Category:Bathing in art]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox person |image = | | name = Lily Mariye | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|9|25}} | birth_place = [[Las Vegas, Nevada]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | yearsactive = | spouse = [[Boney James]] (1985–present) | website = http://www.lilymariye.net/ }} '''Lily Mariye''' is an American television director, filmmaker and actress. ==Early life== Mariye was born in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]] and graduated from [[UCLA]] with a BA in Theater Arts. ==Career== From 1994 to 2009 she had a regular role as nurse [[Lily Jarvik]] on the [[NBC]] television series ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', for which she has won the [[Screen Actors Guild]] Award for Best Ensemble in a Drama Series four times. She has appeared in many films such as ''[[The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas]]'', ''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]'', ''[[The Shadow (1994 film)|The Shadow]]'', ''The New Age'', ''[[The Doctor (1991 film)|The Doctor]]'' and ''[[Extraordinary Measures]]''. Lily has guest-starred in over 25 television shows including ''[[Teen Wolf]]'', ''[[Criminal Minds]]'', ''[[Shameless (U.S. TV series)|Shameless]]'', ''[[NCIS L.A.]]'', ''[[Judging Amy]]'', ''[[Ally McBeal]]'', ''[[Family Ties]]'', ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' and ''[[Chicago Hope]]''. She is also an award-winning theatre actress, performing in New York, Los Angeles and other regional theatres around the country. Lily Mariye's debut feature film as a writer and director, ''Model Minority'' had its world premiere at the 2012 Los Angeles Asian Pacific Film Festival, where it received three awards: Special Jury Outstanding Director, Breakthrough Performance by a New Actor and Outstanding Cinematography as well as being a nominee for the Grand Jury Prize in Narrative Feature Filmmaking. ''Model Minority'' also won Best Micro-Budget Film and Best Female Director at The London Independent Film Festival, and Outstanding Feature at The Sacramento International Film Festival. She has written several full-length screenplays, one of which, ''[[The Shangri-la Cafe]],'' was accepted into the second round of the application process for development in the Sundance Feature Film Labs. ''[[The Shangri-la Cafe]]'' won Best Screenplay at the Ohio International Independent Film Festival and the Gaffers Film Festival, and won her a grant from the [[AFI Conservatory]]'s prestigious Directing Workshop for Women, 13th Cycle. While at AFI she produced and directed an award-winning short film version of the script (Best Short Film Award - Moondance International Film Festival, Best Screenplay Award - Brussels Independent Film Festival). The short film version of ''[[The Shangri-la Cafe]]'' was included on a DVD release of AFI shorts entitled ''Celebrating AFI''. In 2012 Mariye was chosen to participate in the Disney/ABC/DGA Directing Program. In 2016 she directed Episode 14, Season 4 of ABC's ''[[Nashville (season 4)]]'' and Episode 4 after ''[[Nashville (season 5)]]'' moved to CMT. She also directed an episode of Season 2 of Amazon's "Just Add Magic" and episode 17, Season 4 of Freeform's "The Fosters." In 2017 she participated in The CBS Directing Initiative. Also in 2017, Mariye directed episodes of ''[[Chicago P.D. (TV series)]]'', ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' and helmed her third episode on ''[[Nashville (season 6)]]''. In 2018 Mariye directed an episode of CBS's ''[[Criminal Minds]]''. In 2018 she received a DGA Award Nomination at the 70th Annual DGA Awards for Outstanding Directorial Achievement in Children’s Program for her work on "Just Add Magic. ==Personal life== A resident of Los Angeles, Mariye lives with husband, four time Grammy-nominated recording artist, saxophonist [[Boney James]], who also contributed to the soundtracks for ''[[The Shangri-la Cafe]]'' and ''Model Minority''. == Directing Credits == {| class= "wikitable" !Title !Year !Type |- | ''[[Criminal Minds]]'' | 2018 |TV series |- | ''[[Nashville (season 6)|Nashville]]'' | 2018 |TV series |- | ''[[NCIS: Los Angeles]]'' | 2017 |TV series |- | ''[[Chicago P.D. (TV series)|Chicago P.D.]]'' | 2017 |TV series |- | ''[[Nashville (season 5)|Nashville]]'' | 2017 |TV series |- | ''[[The Fosters (2013 TV series)|The Fosters]]'' | 2017 |TV series |- |''[[Just Add Magic (TV series)|Just Add Magic]]'' |2017 |TV series |- | ''[[Nashville (season 4)|Nashville]]'' | 2016 |TV series |- |''Model Minority'' | 2012 | Feature Film |- | ''[[The Shangri-la Cafe]]'' |2000 |Short Film |- |} ==Acting Credits== === Film === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Title ! Director |- | ''[[Extraordinary Measures]]'' | Tom Vaughan |- | [[Hancock (film)|''Hancock'']] | Peter Berg |- | ''[[American Pie Presents: Band Camp]]'' | Dr. Susan Choi |- | ''[[Mighty Joe Young (1998 film)|Mighty Joe Young]]'' (1998 film) | Ron Underwood |- | ''Signs And Wonders'' | Maurice Phillips |- | ''[[The Shadow]]'' | Russell Mulcahy |- | ''California Myth'' | Michel Katz |- | ''[[The New Age]]'' | Michael Tolkin |- | ''[[Ted & Venus]]'' | Bud Cort |- | [[The Doctor (1991 film)|''The Doctor'']] | Randa Haines |- | [[Switch (1991 film)|''Switch'']] | Blake Edwards |- | [[The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas (film)|''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas'']] | Colin Higgins |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{Infobox person | name = Lilyan Chauvin | image = LILYAN CHAUVIN.jpg <!-- only free-content images are allowed for depicting living people. Non-free and "fair use" images, e.g. promo photos, CD/DVD covers, posters, screen captures, etc., will be deleted - see [[WP:NONFREE]] --> | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Lilyan Zemoz | birth_date = {{Birth date|1925|08|06|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], France | death_date = {{death date and age|2008|06|26|1925|08|06|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]], U.S. | occupation = {{hlist|Actress|producer|director}} | years_active= 1950{{spaced ndash}}2007 | spouse = Bernard J. Chauvin ({{abbr|div.|divorced}} 1953) | website = {{URL|lilyanchauvin.com}} }}
'''Lilyan Chauvin''' ({{IPAc-en|l|ɪ|l|i|æ|n|_|tʃ|əʊ|v|ɛ|n}};{{Fix|text=stress?}} {{nee|'''Zemoz'''}}; 6 August 1925{{spaced ndash}}26 June 2008)<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site">{{cite web|work=Lilyan Chauvin Official site|title=Biography|url=http://www.lilyanchauvin.com/Biography.html|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> was a [[French Americans|French-American]] actress, [[Television presenter|television host]], director, writer, and acting teacher. A native of [[Paris]], Chauvin began her career performing on French radio and onstage in England. She relocated to the United States in 1952 to pursue an acting career, and was initially cast in minor television parts before making her film debut in 1957.
Chauvin's career in American films spanned over 60 years, and largely consisted of supporting roles. Some of her credits include ''[[The Other Side of Midnight (film)|The Other Side of Midnight]]'' (1977), ''[[Private Benjamin (1980 film)|Private Benjamin]]'' (1980), the slasher film ''[[Silent Night, Deadly Night]]'' (1984), ''[[Predator 2]]'' (1990), and [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Catch Me If You Can]]'' (2002). She also had a prolific career in television, and guest-starred in such television series as ''[[The X-Files]]'', ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'', ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'', ''[[Friends]]'', ''[[Magnum, P.I.]]'', ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'', ''[[Malcolm in the Middle]]'', ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'', ''[[McCloud (TV series)|McCloud]]'', ''[[Perry Mason (TV series)|Perry Mason]]'', and ''[[Ugly Betty]]''.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
In her later life, Chauvin taught acting and directing at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] and the [[University of Southern California]]. She also served as the [[Vice President]] of Women in Film council. She died in Los Angeles in 2008 of complications resulting from congestive heart failure and [[breast cancer]], the latter of which she battled for four decades.
==Early life== Chauvin was born in [[Paris]], [[Île-de-France]], [[France]],<ref name="opa">{{cite book|last1=Lentz|first1=Harris M. III|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2008: Film, Television, Radio, Theatre, Dance, Music, Cartoons and Pop Culture|date=2009|publisher=McFarland|pages=72–3|isbn= 978-0-786-43482-4 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cH3GCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA72&dq=%22Lilyan+Chauvin%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjc4835vYzVAhXr34MKHcjMDlcQ6AEIMzAC#v=onepage&q=%22Lilyan%20Chauvin%22&f=false|language=en}}</ref> to a French mother, Emilia Speltiens, and an [[Italians|Italian]] father, Pantion Pierre Zemoz.<ref name=laobit/><ref name="t">{{cite news|title=Dorchester Music Hall Opens June 11|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12392732/lilyan_chauvin/|work=The Times|date=3 June 1963|location=Indiana, Hammond|page=6|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = 15 July 2017}} {{Open access}}</ref><ref group=note>An article published in ''The Times'' of Hammond, Indiana, on June 3, 1963, says of Chauvin, "Her father, Pierre, although French-born, had become an American citizen."</ref>
Chauvin began her career working in broadcasting in France. While under contract to a French radio station she had her heart set on becoming a lawyer; however her earnings soon exceeded that of her parents' and she gave serious consideration to making show business her way of life. She studied in Paris at the School of Cinema, and at the [[Jean-Louis Barrault]] School,<ref name="bde">{{cite news|title=New French Beauty Seen Hit on Studio 1|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/12391713/lilyan_chauvin/|work=The Brooklyn Daily Eagle|date=30 August 1953|location=New York, Brooklyn|page=26|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = 15 July 2017}} {{Open access}}</ref> also in Paris.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
==Career== ===Early career and stage=== Chauvin moved to [[New York City]] in 1952<ref name=gg>{{cite web|url=http://www.glamourgirlsofthesilverscreen.com/show/573/Lilyan+Chauvin/index.html|work= Glamour Girls of the Silver Screen |title=The Private Lives and Times] of Lilyan Chauvin|accessdate=19 December 2017}}</ref> and became a naturalized American citizen. She studied with [[Uta Hagen]] and at the [[Actors Studio]] in New York. Chauvin also attended the Berlitz school of Languages and took in American movies every day to improve her English. Already proficient in Spanish, German, Italian, and Russian, she soon became one of the school’s top teachers and they sent her out to coach actors in the accents they needed for various roles.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/><ref name=gg/>
Chauvin's European stage and [[Actors' Equity Association|Actors Equity]] theatre credits include ''[[Macbeth]]'', ''[[Medea]]'', ''[[Silk Stockings]]'', ''[[The Lady of the Camellias|Camille]]'', and ''Three for Today''. She began landing roles in New York television productions including TV's prestigious ''[[Studio One (TV series)|Studio One]]''. Soon after she traveled to Los Angeles and found work in film and television.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
===Transition to film=== Chauvin made her film acting debut in ''Letter from Cairo'' (1953), an episode of the long-running series ''Studio One''. The following year she guest-starred in ''Crusader''. Chauvin made her first motion picture appearance in ''[[Lost, Lonely and Vicious]]'' (1958) and later starred in ''[[Walk Like a Dragon]]'' (1960) and ''[[Bloodlust!]]'' (1961). She also appeared in the [[Elvis Presley]] films ''[[King Creole]]'' (1958) and ''[[Tickle Me]]'' (1965) and the [[Barbra Streisand]] film ''[[Funny Lady]]'' (1975). Other film credits include ''[[Yours, Mine and Ours (1968 film)|Yours, Mine and Ours]]'' (1968), ''[[The Mephisto Waltz]]'' (1971), ''[[The Other Side of Midnight (film)|The Other Side of Midnight]]'' (1977), ''[[Beyond Reason (1977 film)|Beyond Reason]]'' (1977), ''[[Private Benjamin (1980 film)|Private Benjamin]]'' (1980), ''[[Silent Night, Deadly Night]]'' (1984, as the sadistic Mother Superior), ''[[Born in East L.A. (film)|Born in East L.A.]]'' (1987), ''[[Bad Influence (film)|Bad Influence]]'' (1990), ''[[Predator 2]]'' (1990), ''[[Angel Town (film)|Angel Town]]'' (1990), ''[[Universal Soldier (1992 film)|Universal Soldier]]'' (1992), ''[[The Warlord: Battle for the Galaxy]]'' (1998), ''[[Five Aces]]'' (1999), ''[[The Man Who Wasn't There (2001 film)|The Man Who Wasn't There]]'' (2001) and ''[[Catch Me If You Can]]'' (2002).
Chauvin was a series regular on ''[[Days of Our Lives]]'', ''[[Mission Impossible]]'', ''[[General Hospital]]'' and ''[[Falcon Crest]]''. Other television credits include ''[[Adventures of Superman (TV series)|Adventures of Superman]]'', ''[[Combat!]]'', ''[[Baa Baa Black Sheep]]'', ''[[Friends]]'', ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'', ''[[Tyson (1995 film)|Tyson]]'', ''[[Malcolm in the Middle]]'', ''[[Alias (TV series)|Alias]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation|CSI]]'', ''[[Ugly Betty]]'', ''[[The X-Files]]'', and ''[[Murder She Wrote]]''.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
===Directing=== In the industry, Chauvin’s talents are respected equally as a director and actress. Her DGA directing credits include ''[[The Young and the Restless]]'', ''But She Can Type'', ''Celebration 75'' and ''Windows of Heaven''. Chauvin directed productions of ''[[Last Summer at Bluefish Cove]]'', ''Effigies'', ''Seacliffe California'', ''In My Minds Eye'', ''The Happy Time'' and ''The Deepest Hunger''.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
==Other ventures== ===Teaching=== In her later life, Chauvin became a prominent acting and directing coach in Los Angeles, teaching at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] and the [[University of Southern California]].<ref name=laobit>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/latimes/obituary.aspx?pid=112417919|work=Los Angeles Times|title=Lilyan Chauvin Obituary|accessdate=20 December 2017|via=Legacy.com}}</ref> Many of her techniques have become instrumental teaching tools within the industry and have provided inspiration to many other successful educators. As an author and educator she taught internationally at seminars as a keynote speaker, lecturer and adviser.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
As the creator and show runner she co-produced and hosted the television series ''Hollywood Structured'', a comprehensive guide to show business careers, Chauvin explored new facets of the industry each week through interviews with top professionals.<ref>{{cite web|work=TrekToday|title=Lilyan Chauvin Passes Away|date=3 July 2008|accessdate=27 December 2017|url=https://www.trektoday.com/news/030708_04.shtml}}</ref> The 64 episodes covered acting, directing, make up, documentary filmmaking, producing, music, comedy, cinematography, stunt coordinating, modeling, publicity, writing, dancing, sports announcing, production design, entertainment law, agency, casting, union, special effects and more.
Chauvin wrote ''Hollywood Scams & Survival Tactics'', in which she shared many of her own experiences and survival tactics.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
She taught acting, multi-cam cinematography and directing for over 10 years at [[University of Southern California|USC]] and taught acting/directing at [[UCLA]] for two years. Some of Chauvin's acting students were Raquel Welch, Suzanne Somers, Margie Haber, [[Carly Schroeder]], Kin and Wil Shriner, Jennifer Runyon, Kevin Nealon and Rex Steven Sikes. She was a technical advisor and dialogue coach at MGM and worked as a dialogue supervisor/drama coach at Warner Brothers. For many years she ran the '''Women in Film Director's Workshop''' which drew large numbers of people from the various aspects of filmmaking.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
===Still photography=== Chauvin's work with stationary images included taking a photograph of author [[William Faulkner]] that was published in [[The Atlantic|The Atlantic Monthly]] magazine and was to be used on dust jackets of Faulkner books.<ref name=bde/>
==Accolades== Twice nominated for [[Emmy Award]]s (for ''[[The Young and the Restless]]'' and ''[[Baa Baa Black Sheep]]''),{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}} Chauvin won the 1991 Angel Award for ''Hollywood Structured'', which was co-produced by Chauvin, Julie Johnson and Irene Lamothe. Chauvin appeared weekly as the host on this cable program with, among others, [[Jacqueline Bisset]], [[Linda Gray]], [[Morey Amsterdam]], [[Danny Glover]], [[Henry Mancini]], [[Anne Francis]], [[Carmen Zapata]] and others.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
==Affiliations== Chauvin was on the Women’s Steering Committee of the Directors Guild of America and had over 35 credits as a DGA Director since 1979. She was a member of Screen Actors Guild, the Writers Guild of America, the American Federation of Television and Radio Artist and Equity. Committed to furthering women's causes, especially in the industry, Chauvin was a 39-year member of Women in Film. She served on the organization's Board five times, twice as the Board's Vice President.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
==Personal life== Chauvin was married to Bernard Chauvin, whom she divorced in [[Florida]] in 1953.<ref name=gg/> She retained his surname for the remainder of her career.<ref name=gg/> In the 1960s, Chauvin was diagnosed with [[breast cancer]], which she would battle intermittently for the following four decades.<ref name="Lilyan Chauvin Biography Site"/>
===Death=== Chauvin died at her [[Studio City, Los Angeles|Studio City]], [[Los Angeles]] home on 26 June 2008, aged 82.<ref name=laobit/> Her death was attributed to complications from breast cancer and [[congestive heart disease]].<ref name=laobit/><ref name=opa/>
